Reviews.Title: “Outstanding Service; Very Good Conditions”
Reviews.Author: acbc1966
Reviews.Content: I'm a resident of Oahu and have stayed twice at Turtle Bay within the past 18 months for a few days when visitors came from the mainland. My most recent stay was 5 nights, in the main hotel (not one of the beach bungalows. First off, the service by all staff was without parallel, and was the best I have ever received. Check-in staff was friendly, and accommodated a room change we requested (to get a better view) the evening we arrived, even AFTER we'd checked in. The food at the restaurants is a little pricey, but no more than you'd expect at a quality resort hotel, and the quality is excellent. We splurged one night dining at '21 Degrees North' and everything was wonderful. Still, decent off-site restaurants are available in Haleiwa, a 15 minute drive away, if you're on a budget. Turtle Bay sits on a gorgeous site with a beautiful beach, nice beach amenities, and other, more private beaches a short walk away. Pool looks nice, but I'm not a pool swimmer so can't speak from experience. However, there is a downside...aspects of the hotel are really showing their wear & tear, and I really noticed a deterioration since my previous stay 18 months ago. Some of the upholstery in the lobby was stained, the air conditioning outlet in our room was rusting, and the hall carpets were fraying around the edges. The kicker was when the bathroom lock in our room jammed the last evening we were there, so engineering staff had to come and forcibly remove the lock so we could gain access. Needless to say, this could not have happened at a worse time, being the last afternoon of our stay. I get the impression that ownership/management is letting things go somewhat. I suppose this is understandable, as the property is for sale, and according to local papers, if a sale doesn't occur within the next 6 months the loan holders will foreclose. Moreover, the state of Hawaii has expressed interest in purchasing the property, which complicates things. This is really a shame, because Turtle Bay is one of Oahu's best kept secrets as far as a luxury resort in a gorgeous, country location, away from Waikiki craziness. On the other hand, if you'd prefer Waikiki nightlife, Turtle Bay is not the place for you. I would highly recommend a stay at Turtle Bay, but you may want to check some Honolulu papers before you come to see what the status is.

Reviews.Title: “Good enough for Sean Penn, good enough for me!”
Reviews.Author: ChefUzma
Reviews.Content: Turtle bay is great for a relaxing vacation. My husband and I spent about 5 days there. We did a couples massage in the outdoor hut which was absolutely amazing. We took a horseback ride around the property and saw the locations where LOST is filmed. Sean Penn was there with his whole family which was pretty neat to see (i got a picture of him!!). It was an all-around great vacation, exactly what my husband and I needed.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful vacation”
Reviews.Author: Shellerina
Reviews.Content: We had a great time on our Hawaiian vacation staying at the Turtle Bay Resort on Oahu. We flew in and drove right to our resort and were blown away by their magnificent Lobby with views of the Pacific, and open air style. This trip was for my husband and I. I had read reviews of their guestrooms and was a little scared, but it turned out to be fine. Everything else about the hotel is 4 star level, but the rooms are probably more like 3 star. But they have amazing views!! We were in room 508 and had views of the pool and the ocean. It was gorgeous! The pool view was especially at night when the tiki torches were going and the pool was glowing. It's not too noisy either because the pool closes at 8:00pm. (It's gets dark early in Hawaii we noticed..) The bed was fine, but not of the Marriot Luxe variety I love. But still adequate. The bathroom was very roomy and had a fridge and coffeemaker and sink in a separate area from the other part of the bathroom which was great for getting ready in the morning. The decor is simple but we like those straightlines and it didn't detract from the view outside. We had an oceanfront King room. It had a good sized patio and we sat out and ate breakfast a few times. The drawers that we could use to put our clothes in had a weird smell and I didn't like that. But there is a large closet with hangers. The pools are great! One big pool, one small kiddie pool. Then there is another pool that has a waterslide and waterfall in it. We liked that one a lot. All have views of the ocean. There are also two hot tubs. The grounds of the resort are SO incredibly beautiful. We loved walking around and night and getting dinner or a drink at Ola's. They have pool and beach side towel stands and a free hour of snorkling is included in your resort fee. We had so much fun snorkling so make sure you give that a try. Service was excellent. We checked out a beach cottage one day and they are beautiful. I would pay the price for one if I could get a deal, but not for the rack rate. We went just before peak season and the rates were great for all rooms. We ate at Lei Lei's which was GOOD (pricey) and Ola's which was also delicious (and more pricey). We had a bite to eat at the Bay Club one night. We bought oatmeal, cereal and milk on the way (at Foodland) and so we didn't have to fork out money for that which saved a lot. Plus we're not really big breakfast eaters. (We asked housekeeping to bring us bowls and spoons which they quickly did....good service there.) Oh, I almost forgot, they have the most wonderful turn down service which we recieved 4 out of our 6 nights. They even leave a little treat wrapped in a banana leaf and a sheet of paper telling the weather, sunrise and sunset times and activities going on for the next day. And they turn on the most relaxing music. That was so wonderful to come home too. We didn't do the spa because the prices are insane, but if you have the money, we did see the little outdoor hut that you can get massages in (they also have a full indoor spa) and that looked to die for! Right on the edge of the property next to the ocean... We ate a lot of properties off-hotel because we were trying to stay within our budget and we had a LOT of great meals. If you drive east or west you come to little towns that have great food at reasonable prices. We tried Giovanni's shrimp shack in Kahuku. Yummy! We also tried the shrimp shack just on the southern end of Haleiwa which was SOOO good (Macky's...he's the best...great service...friendly guy!). We had the lemon pepper shrimp...Oh man, my mouth is watering already. We went to Matsumoto's twice for shave ice. Try it with icecream in the bottom! Yum!! Haleiwa is a really fun little town. Lots of shopping places, restaurants and stuff. One thing to note is we shared meals a lot because the portions tended to be huge. We ordered the nachos to share at Cholos in Haleiwa and even though we shared, we still couldn't finish it. Oh, and we did the luau at the resort which was expensive and I was a little nervous if it would be worth it, but it was GREAT! The performers were from the nearby Polynesian Cultural Center and the food was very good. The show they put on was excellent and you eat outdoors, with a beautiful view of the setting sun and the ocean and foliage of the property. We LOVED it. The resort is beautiful and we would definitely go back. The northshore is such a beautiful area. We drove down to Waikiki one day and it was fun and busy and great, but we are SO glad we stayed on the northshore. It's more manageable and quiet and it's not so crowded with people and buildings so you can enjoy Hawaii's quiet peacefulness. We saw a lot of weddings on the Saturday we were there (We stayed Mon-Sun) and all I can say is, what a beautiful place to get married. We will be back.

Reviews.Title: “great place to stay”
Reviews.Author: rockytoprb
Reviews.Content: Very nice place to stay if on upper floors, some of the lower flowers have limited views. Nice beaches, golf courses, restaurants, pools, views. Very secluded. If you don't want to eat at the resort, it is a long drive to nearest restaurants.

Reviews.Title: “best hotel in oahu can't wait to come back again.”
Reviews.Author: myang
Reviews.Content: We stayed at turtle bay resort for 2 nights, 6/1/08, 6/2/08. This is a very very nice hotel. We had a ocean front room, the room was very very clean, and very spacious; it got perfect ocean view. The beach in the resort was just perfect. the water was very clam, like a bath tub.... perfect for swim and snorkel. the staffs were very friendly, and ready to help on whatever questions guests may have. also the resort got very nice pool and hot tubs next to the ocean. I really can't find anything bad about this resort, it's a true resort. the resort and its room look just like what it shows in the hotel photos.

Reviews.Title: “Perhaps our expectations were too high for what is supposedly a four-star resort”
Reviews.Author: another_believer
Reviews.Content: As the first stop on our honeymoon we wanted to choose a place to stay that would offer a relaxing beginning to our trip of a lifetime. After extensive research this seemed to be the place to be. What we were looking for was a beautiful place that would offer a variety of activities, restaurants, relaxation and romance. What we got was a pool full of screaming children, helicopters and loud golf carts driving by the beachside massage room while services were in progress, mediocre food at ridiculously expensive restaurants and a general lack of the personal touch one would expect from a four-star resort. I don't think it out of line to expect a $16 pizza and a $30 buffet not to contain a multitude of bugs. I also don't think it outrageous to expect a level of professionalism from the pool staff that doesn't include ogling guests. While their spa facilities are very nice, they are located right along a heavily traveled pathway where passers-by are free to stare at you as you sit (in absolutely nothing but a flimsy robe). Needless to say, this takes away from the relaxation element of the treatment. It would be nice to say that this was the only issue that we had with the spa facilities but sadly, it isn't. During the latter part of our treatment an hour-long yoga class was held a mere 5 meters away from where we were sitting (in the very same room). The staff is friendly and welcoming however management has clearly not encouraged them to go the extra mile for their guests. I would highly recommend bringing your own food and any potential toiletries you may require on your stay, You will find that no meal can be had for under $20. If you're a fan of the many fruits and juices available on the island, I recommend purchasing them elsewhere. Be prepared for possible (random) construction beginning before 9am and slamming doors at all hours. Also take into account that the price of any and all services delivered to your room will, in reality, cost about twice what is listed after taxes, fees and delivery charges. Frankly, we won't be returning or recommending this place to anyone. It's just not worth the cost. It's that simple.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Property”
Reviews.Author: chrisw03
Reviews.Content: My wife and I stayed at Turtle Bay resort it was one of the best vacation of our lives. The property was beautiful and the horseback riding on site was great. The service was wonderful, and the staff was unbelievably pleasant, even the security guard was friendly and told us some of the best restaurants on the island. The rooms were very nice and the overall stay was perfect, could not ask for anything more.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful and Relaxing”
Reviews.Author: Husker4301
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Olsons Villa at Turtle Bay Resort in May. We felt we had the both of best worlds getting a larger unit then the hotel for less money but also being able to dine and enjoy all that the resort had to offer. We were just yards from the beach and the villa was very nice. The only problems we encountered was getting into the condo later then we planned. The owners failed to get our key to us before we left and we had to wait for a person to get them to us who was over an hour away. When he finally did show up around 4:30 the maid still hadn't cleaned the room. This was a bit upsetting to us after traveling 12 hours and wanting to get to a place to relax and clean up before dinner. We also did not get any instructions on where the lockers were or what was in them for our use. We ended up renting snorkeling gear for 25.00 which we could have avoided if we had known. We were disappointed in the snorkeling there compared to other places we have been. The security person there at the villas also did not know how to get into the locker and had to get someone to help her. Other then these issues the villa was comfortable and quiet and the resort was beautiful. The resort does close down early with not too much night life, restaurants were closed by nine so if you plan on going out late think again. The food was very good there but plan on spending a good amount. We would strongly recommend this resort for its quiet relaxing setting but if night life and excitement is what you like Wakkiki is the place to go. Kara & Mike Buck, Lincoln Nebraska

Reviews.Title: “Very nice stay - Beach Cottages a Must”
Reviews.Author: Target08
Reviews.Content: We recently stayed at the resort for 8 days for our honeymoon. Like everyone else we were reluctant to book with the hotel due to some of the bad reviews but it was a very nice stay. We stayed in the beach cottages (room 141) and it was beautiful. Room: If you want privacy ask for this room since it is located the furthest from the hotel (5-10 minute walk). For couples ask for a King cottage which will have a wet bar, a king bed and a little more square feet. The beach is located right in front of the cottage. There is a little backyard with a lanai, a shared hammock and where people walk thru (sometimes) to go on trails. Note there are roosters roaming around the grounds. We found them interesting at first but the early morning wake up calls got annoying. The local birds were also interesting at first but got REALLY annoying if you eat on the lanai. The room was spacious and beachy but the TV needs updating. The central air worked OK but could've been better. The room is a little dark with the lights on if you don't open the blinds completely. The bathroom was bright with a large tub and walk-in shower. Maid service was excellent and room very clean. Yes the room smells a little musty from the ocean air. We both received leis (free) and the gift basket (extra - not worth it) upon arrival as well as drinks and champagne. You get a fruit of the day everyday as well as some coconut macaroons (wrap in banana leaves) at nighttime. Food: room service was good. The seafood chowder was excellent. Palm Terrace buffet just so-so. 21 degrees was OK. Ola's was the Best of the bunch (and that would be the only dining option that is worth a repeat visit). The Sunday brunch is also worth a try. The Lua was terrible (food was poor) but entertainment OK if you want to experience one. Spa: we did the seaside couples massage and it was excellent. Spa facilities excellent. Grounds: Nice and clean. We didn't utilize the pools or hot tubes but they seemed nice. The beaches right in front of the cottages are beautiful but rocky and wavy. You have to go to either coves for a sandy beach and calmer waters. We went to the further cove past the horse stables (about 20-30 minutes walk) where absolutely no one went to (probably because of the walk) but you essentially get your own beach but it was amazing. We did that twice. Tennis courts, horse stable, golf courses we didn't use. Hotel staff were nice and friendly and the main hotel seem decent. Other: Foodland supermarket about 10-15 minute drive either way, out of the resort. Ted's bakery so-so (everyone thinks this place is good because there is nothing else on the North Shore). Shrimp trucks very good. We liked Mack's the best. Local fruits stand interesting. Starbucks also down the road. Not much dining options outside the resort on the North Shore. Can't stand the slow speed limits on the roads (45mph limit on the highways, 25-35 on roads). Polynesian Cultural Center is OK. Dole Plantation OK. Waikiki very busy. Aloa Moana shopping center is huge and beautiful (a must for shoppers). Diamond Head hike was nice. Manoa Falls hike so-so. Kayaking in Kailua was excellent. Food tour (hole in the wall tour) was good.

Reviews.Title: “A good, solid property on Oahu's North Shore”
Reviews.Author: tequilatamm
Reviews.Content: We stayed for two nights at the Turtle Bay Resort during a trip for my 40th birthday. For years we had been wanting to stay at the Turtle Bay Resort, but it always got such bad reviews that we never did, opting instead for hopping to other islands. Recently, the reviews have been getting better, so we decided to save the money and time it would take going to a different island, and give it a try, inserting it in between two stays in Waikiki. We drove up to Turtle Bay and arrived at about 2:45pm as we had some spa treatments scheduled for 3:30pm. This was the only portion of the stay that we were disappointed with, as we had booked a Beach Cottage, and it wasn't yet ready for us. We thought 3pm was a bit later than acceptable to release our room (it was still being cleaned) especially when we had booked over $1000 worth of spa packages that they knew we would be arriving for around this time. Fortunately, the Beach Cottages have their own concierge, and the gentleman who was down at the Beach Cottage area when we arrived organized everything so that he could get our luggage into our room while we were at the spa. He was very friendly and accommodating, so that sorted out that problem. The spa itself was one of the better ones I've had the pleasure to go to. There was a waiting area in an outdoor shaded patio area overlooking the gardens and sea, where you could wait between treatments. The locker room also had a steam room, something not present in enough hotels, which was lovely. The treatment staff were good and professional, and I specifically enjoyed the massage, which was excellent... not too hard, and not too soft. In fact, I had a facial, which I usually don't enjoy, and it left my face so soft that I ended up going back to enquire about the products they had used on my face and purchasing two of them. We gathered from other reviews that people who had stayed at the Beach Cottages generally wrote good reviews, while others wrote bad reviews, and we certainly weren't disappointed. I should point out a few things about these cottages. Firstly, they are not freestanding. There are 3 cottages within one structure, with the back patios separated by walls, so you do hear your neighbors a bit when they're outside. We had a rather large family with young kids staying next door, and we could certainly hear them, but not through the walls, just outside when they were on the grassy areas. I should also point out that we had a King Bed beach cottage. I believe there are kings, queens and two doubles depending on the cottage. They told us that the King Bed cottages were larger, and also have a wet bar in the living room area, which the others don't. They weren't telling a lie. Judging from the width of the rooms, our room was MUCH larger than most of those around us, so it's worth getting a King if you can. Our cottage was absolutely palatial, with the bathroom being quite large too, with a separate and VERY large tub (one of the largest I've seen... my husband is a big guy and usually doesn't fit in them, but he fit in this one), and separate toilet area within the bathroom. The bathroom was a white, beachy theme and very comfortable. We had the good fortune to meet up with the Sales Manager who showed us the two other room types available on the property. One is called Villas. The villas are brand new, and Turtle Bay manages them for the owners, so they are like condos. I have to say that if I had a large family, this would be the only option I would consider. The villas have a kitchen, VERY modern amenities, washer/dryer and up to 4 bedrooms. They are located next door to the hotel, and have their own pool and barbecue area. You can use both the villa pool plus all the hotel's regular facilities, including their beach. Don't think normal Hawaiian condo here... these are first class executive and worth staying in. As much as I liked the Beach Cottage, if I went back, I'd probably opt for one of these. Next we had a look at a few of the traditional rooms in the regular hotel building. From what I'd read on tripadvisor, I had gathered that these rooms were old and tired and somewhat moldy smelling... not very nice at all. So I was pleasantly surprised when we entered one and it was quite good really. OK, maybe not the newest or poshest room I've EVER seen, but I'd happily stay in one of these. Most of these rooms have ocean views, and are rather large, with older style but quite acceptable bathrooms. I did notice that they seemed to use air freshener to try and cover up what smelled like a bit of a moldy smell, but it really wasn't a problem for me. If you're particularly sensitive, you might not like this room, but if you're not, it would be quite fine. These rooms have either a full balcony or something called a Juliet Balcony, which is a sort of curved afterthought of a balcony, still large enough to sit on, but only just. The most recent owners added these Juliet balconies to make more of the rooms have an outside feel. The lowest level in the hotel lacks any balcony, and merely has a floor to ceiling window that opens fully, so if you want to sit outside, make sure you request not to be on the lowest floor. Other than that, I found both other types of balconies quite acceptable. The grounds of the hotel are as good as any resort on any outlying island, and the beach actually has sand, but coral if you swim out, so it's quite snorkel-able and comfortable. Again, I felt this was on par with any of the resorts on outlying islands. As far as food, we were a bit late getting around to eating the night we got there, after our spa treatments, so we went down to the Pub Style food outlet, which was very sparse and ugly and unpleasant. After a few enquiries, we found out that Lei Lei's, which is located at the golf club, was still opened, and so we got a ride in a golf cart down there. It's not far and walkable, but we saw many people catching rides to and from the restaurant in the golf cart, and they are happy to do it. Having spoke with several staff around the place, Lei Lei's seems to be considered one of the best food outlets at Turtle Bay if not on the North Shore, and our food was certainly good, and pretty good value for money. We had breakfast included in our rate, so we ate both mornings at the buffet breakfast, which has a nice view of the ocean. I would call this buffet typical of breakfast buffets. It was certainly nothing special, but did provide a good, solid morning meal, nothing wrong with it. We also ate lunch one day at the poolside bar area. Other Tripadvisor members have complained about the slow service, and I would have to agree. It took about 45 minutes to get a couple burgers, and they actually tried to bring us the wrong thing prior to getting our correct order to us. The food itself was fine but nothing special, and the service was less than average. Finally, the public lawn areas outside our Beach Cottage were very nice and faced the sunset. It was quite pleasant, and on par with some of the nicer resorts we've stayed at in Fiji. All in all, given the choice between an outlying island or a simple drive up the coast to Turtle Bay, I would definitely consider going back to this hotel again.

Reviews.Title: “Great place to relax and rejuvenate”
Reviews.Author: FreqravelerSteve
Reviews.Content: Turtle Bay is a hideaway on the North Beach of Oahu. No crowds, no traffic, just great for getting away. I used it to rejuvenate after a grueling couple months. You can sit by the pool, dine at Ola's, surf, play tennis, and enjoy the fitness center or have a drink at the bar. We did it all. The only negatives was the nightlife was not too great. You are just too remote. However, the beaches around the area are classic surfing locations with plenty of sand for sunbathing and enjoying the water. Great place to find turtles. If you're looking for Waikiki, go south. However, if you're looking for rest and relaxation, go north.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful resort, OK room”
Reviews.Author: JenniferMathews
Reviews.Content: My husband and myself stayed at Turtle Bay Resort for our 10 year wedding anniversary. When we arrived at Turtle Bay we were happy to see how nice it looked and how friendly everyone was. I had read some reviews about Turtle Bay and was a little nervous as to what we were in store for. We had a room on the 3rd floor overlooking the pool area, we had a standard room and a big lanai (the lanai was nice), the room was like I mentioned a standard room (not a 5 star room that I was hoping to get). I had read in the reviews that the rooms were dated and needed to be remodeled, that was very true. Our room had old cracked tile on the bathroom floor, it needed repainting, the carpet was a little sticky and the shower didn't have a lot of water pressure. Having said that, we were not in the room a lot so we could deal with it. It was kept clean (except I could tell that they didn't give us "clean" glasses, I had used on the day before and it still had my lipstick mark on it!!!). As much as we paid for the room I was just thinking that it would be a little nicer than it was. The resort is beautiful and breathtaking, the restaurants were OK, we ate at the Bay Club twice and LeiLeis once, we had a rental car, which I highly recommend because you are not close to anything, so we were able to go out to some other restaurants in other towns. There is a Foodland pretty close by, I would recommend you going there and getting some breakfast and lunch stuff because food is very expensive, even at the grocery store. The pool was nice and big, get a beach chair early because they get gone fast. You don't even have to pack a beach towel, TB will provide you with a card and you take that card to a "towel stand" and they will give you a beach towel and when you finished using the towel, return it to get your card back (they will charge you $25 if you loose the card). The resort charges a $20 resort fee (you get the newspaper, 1 hour snorkel gear, and some other things). The parking is terrible unless you choose valet, which is $10 a day. There is public beach parking which makes it extremely hard to park anywhere close to the resort. So needless to say, we paid for valet almost everyday. The beach area is OK, we went one time and it was kind of rocky on the bottom. We spent most of our beach time at Waimea Beach Park which has a great beach area. It is not too far away from the resort. Be sure to check out Dole Plantation, Pearl Harbor, Diamond Head and drive the Kalanianaole Highway (that drive is spectacular) and eat some shaved ice. All in all, I enjoyed TB, the beauty of the resort made up for our "standard" room.

Reviews.Title: “Nice room, good ocean views, more relaxing than Waikiki, good snorkeling”
Reviews.Author: krdkrd
Reviews.Content: My wife and I went to Oahu for a conference she had to attend in Honolulu. We only had a couple of extra days to stay after the conference was over, so we decided to stay at Turtle Bay Resort on the North Shore rather than island hopping. We had a deluxe ocean view room which was quite nice. Good sized balcony with a couple of chairs. I think the only real difference between the "deluxe" and regular ocean view room is the larger balcony. The smaller balconies barely seemed to have room for the two chairs out there. The beach is beautiful, and you can snorkel right out front. (2 1-hour snorkel rentals per day are included in the "resort fee." I'm not sure what else the resort fee includes. Unfortunately they don't really spell it out, and that is all I used it for, although it also seemed to include parking.) It's a big complex with several restaurants, golf and horseback riding. We ate at Ola for dinner which is on-site on the beach, which was very good, and did a-la carte breakfast at the breakfast place, which was pretty good. The breakfast buffet seemed overpriced, but within the norm for this kind of hotel ($20-$25, I think). The place is about an hour from Honolulu. It's a nice drive with a lot of small beach access points along the way. Dole Plantation, Waimea Falls Park and the Polynesian Cultural Center are all close by. Also, toward Laie on the way to the Polynesian Cultural Center are "shrimp trucks" which had great fresh shrimp. The beaches on-site were uncrowded, the scenery is beautiful, and all of the staff was polite and helpful. We would definitely go back. It's a nice chill alternative to Honolulu if you find yourself in Oahu. It is far from the airport -- I'd say you would pretty much want a rental car if you are staying here. The cost of taking a cab to and from the airport would likely be much more than renting a car for an entire week.

Reviews.Title: “Nice, but this is no 4-star”
Reviews.Author: Marc_Majka
Reviews.Content: My wife and I went to Oahu for our anniversary, and spent 9 days at the Turtle Bay Resort. We've vacationed before on Maui, Kauai, and the big island of Hawai'i, so we're no strangers to the islands and what you can expect from a hotel / resort. There are some great reviews here in TripAdvisor, and you can have a very good time at Turtle Bay, but while Turtle Bay Resort is very nice, I've got to say that it's not a four-star hotel. I went there expecting that, and I was a bit disappointed. The rooms are a bit old. Our walls could have used a cleaning or a new paint job. The tiles in our bathroom had been re-enameled at some time (they used to be pink), but the enamel was peeling in a couple of spots. The room amenities were nice, but just a bit too basic to consider this a 4 star resort. We ate primarily at Ola, and we liked the food and the service. We had dinner twice at the Palm Terrace. The first time the service was just awful. I'll pin this on the waiter, who wasn't qualified to server burgers at a fast-food restaurant. Although he was the immediate cause of the bad service, why was he there in the first place? We returned there again for a buffet, and the service was good that time (different waiter). The food at Palm Terrace was OK, but nothing special. We also tried 21 Degrees North and enjoyed both the food and the service. It wasn't as pricey as I had thought it would be. The selection of Martinis was fun and the drinks we had were tasty. Lei Lei's (at the Golf Course) was also OK, but nothing special. The food and the service was alright, but decor was totally bland. Since we spent a reasonable amount of time lounging by the pool, we also got a few lunches from the Hang 10 Bar and Grill. The Mahi-Mahi fish wraps were great. The service was good when you could get it, but the staff weren't doing the rounds of the lounge chairs very frequently. The pools were fine, and the water-slide was fun. I found the hot-tub to be way too chemical. Beyond the Hotel itself, we liked the beaches, which are so wonderfully less crowded than Waikiki where we had spent the previous few days. There are some nice walking trails, and a small sheltered swimming / snorkeling beach. Bring some good thick-soled sandals if you want to walk on the lava rock on the beach! My wife and I enjoy outdoor / nature activities. The options are much more limited on Oahu than on Maui, Kauai, or Hawai'i. We visited Waimea canyon which was very pretty, but it's a small area. We tried to get to Sacred Falls State Park (sounds nice!), but couldn't find any access to it from the road. Maybe we missed the sign. We did a nice hike to Maunawili Falls (south of Kailua). Slightly strenuous up-and-down hill, and watch out for slippery rocks when you cross the stream, which you need to do several times. I went for an unplanned swim in the stream, and a planned one at the waterfall. Nice, but nothing like the amazing waterfalls on the road to Hana on Maui. Some other notes about the North Shore. Don't plan to find too many good restaurants near Turtle Bay. You can get a plate of shrimp from numerous places between Turtle Bay and Kahuku, but restaurants are scarce. The best places we found were in Haleiwa. Banzai Sushi was great! We also had a very nice meal at Haleiwa Joe's. Go there for great sunset views (although it was too cloudy the night we went). Bottom line: We enjoyed our stay. If you want to get away from the crowds and you want to be on Oahu, this is the place. However, if you really just want nature and island beauty, Oahu is not the best choice of the islands.

Reviews.Title: “Turtle Bay is a great hotel choice”
Reviews.Author: CritiquerCA
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at Turtle Bay for a four-day getaway. The property is beautiful and one of the highlights each morning was going for a run on one of the resort's walking/running trails. There are a few different trails to choose from and they go along the beach, through the sand, along the golf course and through shaded forested areas. Another daily activity we enjoyed was tennis. There was good availability on the courts the ball machine is just $30/hr. The room was nice, clean and we had a great view of the ocean. Next time I'd probably get one of the cottages since the location is wonderful and they all have nice sitting areas that look over a greenbelt and the ocean. The staff was wonderful--everyone from the cleaning staff, to the restaurants to the front desk were all friendly and helpful. Keep in mind that there is not much shopping or dining in the area (the hotel's restaurants are about it), so your options are fairly limited. Haleiwa is the largest town and is about 20 min. away. I highly recommend Ola Restaurant, which is on the hotel property and overlooks the nice swimming area/beach. You may want to stop at the Foodland in Pupukea (about 10 min. from the hotel on your way in) and pick up some snacks, beer and wine for your room (all rooms have refrigerators). Snorkeling is good at Pupukea and be sure to go to Sunset and Waimea beaches. Waimea Falls Park is a nice place to visit, though the waterfall was a disappointment (only a trickle). The grounds are well worth the visit and there are some beautiful peacocks that wander around the property.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it”
Reviews.Author: TexasLexus
Reviews.Content: This was our third trip to Hawaii. The first two trips were spent in Waikiki where we experienced the Hawaii that The National Tourism Industry sells. We wanted to try something new this time so we ventured to the north shore’s Turtle Bay Resort. My wife and I were a little concerned of what to expect after reading some of the reviews here. We decided to go with an open mind and draw our own conclusions. What we discovered was a little slice of heaven on a pineapple. We were greeted by friendly valet and bell service. Checking in was a breeze and friendly as well. We almost felt like they had us confused with someone else because everyone was so friendly and accommodating. Come to find out, that’s just the “Hawaiian way” as friendliness comes natural on the relaxed north shore of Oahu. We booked an ocean front room (5th floor) with a large lanai, April 20-30. The room itself was basic, nice décor, painted walls some nice pictures, a fridge, coffee maker, desk w/2 nice chairs. The best wall of all would be the floor to ceiling glass one with the electric curtains and the sliding glass door to the lanai. We spent many hours drinking coffee on the lanai each morning/night enjoying the ocean breezes and the sound of the crashing waves below. We were lucky enough to see the whales early in our stay. We felt safe enough to sleep with our sliding glass door open each night to continue enjoying the sounds. There was a nice comfortable bed with 4 fluffy pillows. A smaller not so fluffy pillow (my preference) was found zipped up in a storage bag in the large closet on the shelf above the safe. There was a TV in a nice cabinet but we never once turned it on. The bathroom was large with a nice marble floor and a really nifty shower. There was a nice embroidered Turtle Bay stuffed turtle on our bed when we entered the room. The cost was $19.95 which seemed reasonable for a unique souvenir so we adopted him and took him home with us. The restaurants were all very good. The Palm Terrace was decent but the buffet seemed over priced. After we tried the buffet for breakfast our first day we found the coffee cart with fresh fruits and pastries in the lobby to be a better fit for us (we‘re not big breakfast eaters). The coffee barista’s were always very pleasant. Ola’s (2x) and 21 Degrees were superb. We saw Forgetting Sarah Marshall the day before we left and felt like we’d been to Ola’s before. Hang Ten was very good. Lei-Lei’s (4x) was the absolute best! These guys are on their game and hitting the ball long and straight down the fairway. Located on the golf course, this has to be one of the best places to eat on the island. Everything we tried on our visits (all dinner) was not just good but great! Caesars dressing has to be made from scratch, we loved it. Hint: save room for desert afterwards. The valet offers golf cart service to carry you to and from Lei-Lei’s. Let the waiter know you’re ready to leave when he brings you the check and your chariot awaits before your done paying the bill. If you decide to walk from/to the hotel, it’s not that far away and a very romantic stroll. We ate lunch on the north shore almost every day. There’s a terrific spot 8-10 miles down the east shore called The Tropic’aina Bar & Grill with a couple hundred orchids throughout the very pretty garden and lots of tropical caged birds. Shrimp trucks scatter the north shore. We liked the “Aloha Chef” best but every one of them were good. Just read the signs on the trucks, they all claim to be #1 or they’re world famous! A stop by Ted’s Bakery was in order almost every day too. You’ll pass it on the way to the hotel from the airport, make a mental note to yourself. The Machedamia nut cream pie was awesome. The shops/boutiques on the property had nice selections and were not over priced which was a pleasant surprise. There’s plenty of shopping in Hale’iwa and also down the east side of the island in small shops scattered along the road. You won’t find Macy’s, Nordstrom, Neiman Marcus, Gucci or Armani. but that suited us perfectly, that‘s not why we went to the island. The Polynesian Cultural Center is about 4 miles down the eastern shore and worth a stop. You’ll find a plethora of shops inside the PCC. The weekly luau at Turtle Bay was sold out to a realtors convention on the Friday we were there so we took in the luau at the PCC. Very nicely done with a great show afterwards. . We enjoyed the hotel pool and the snorkeling in the bay was also very nice. There is lots of lava rock on the beach to the west of the hotel., wear sandals if you head this way. This is the best place to watch the turtles in the evening. It’s a good idea to stay on or close to the horse trail (watch your step, LOL!) It’s a romantic walk along the shore and through the tropical vegetation. You’ll see a small tree on the lava rock peninsula and this is where the turtles like to hang out at dusk. The east side bay is mostly sandy but still, watch your step. There was a N-NW swell while we were there so we got to watch the surfers at Sunset, Banzai and Rocky Point. We also enjoyed some body surfing ourselves at Pounders (about ½- ¾ mile past the PCC). Some big waves were there after the N-NW swell passed through making the name of the beach obvious. There’s 8-10 beautiful beaches on the east shore that you can find yourself all alone at times. Be careful of thieves, just because you’re on vacation doesn’t mean the bad guys are too. The helicopter ride was incredible and worth it. The day we scheduled our ride was windy so we swayed quite a bit during our ride. The pilot wasn’t bothered by the wind so we didn’t worry (too much). If you’re a golfer, I couldn’t imagine a nicer place to stay. The hotel charged $9.95 a day for parking. That may seem a little high but after we parked for 3 hours and 10 minutes at The Hilton Hawaiian Village to the tune of $24.50, that made $9.95 a day seem like a bargain. We couldn’t wait to get away from Waikiki and back to the north shore To sum it up, we’ll give Turtle Bay a solid 5* rating. What they offer in hospitality and surroundings can’t be compared any where on the island. We understand that you just can’t make everyone happy hence some of the negative comments. Basically, if you’re looking for the “Royal Treatment” try the Royal Hawaiian. If you’re looking for the “Hawaiian Treatment” head to Turtle Bay, you won‘t be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: “Great stay at Turtle Bay!”
Reviews.Author: malia311
Reviews.Content: I'm from Honolulu but this was my first time staying at Turtle Bay. My boyfriend and I decided to stay there for one night for our anniversary. It was great! We got a kama'aina rate on a deluxe ocean view room. Check in was very easy. Their lobby is beautiful! There were 2 parrots that are set up between the lobby and the elevators so you can talk to them when you pass by :) The room was very spacious with a very comfortable bed and a nice size lanai with 2 chairs. From there we could see surfers and had a great view of the sunset. It was so nice falling asleep to the sound of the ocean. The room had a fridge (but no microwave) and plenty of toiletries and we even got complimentary Turtle Bay t-shirts. There was lots of closet space and a good sized bathroom with 2 sinks. I liked how the alarm clock/radio had an ipod dock built in. We ate lunch at the Hang Ten bar & grill by the pool which was slightly pricey, but to be expected at a resort like this. The food was delicious and we watched the surfers and the people swimming in the pool while we ate. For dinner we went to Ola's which was really good! The pools were very nice! There's a smaller one with a waterfall and a water slide but the big pool was actually warmer. The jacuzzi was packed with people every time I looked over there so I didn't go in it. At night we went to the Bay club bar for some drinks. There was live entertainment (someone singing & playing guitar), shuffleboard, pool, darts, and lots of plasma TVs. We stayed there drinking mai tais and playing pool until they closed. A week after I stayed here the movie Forgetting Sarah Marshall came out. Besides it being hilarious, it was really cool to see cause they filmed most of the movie at the resort and all the restaurant scenes were filmed at Ola's. I can't wait to go back!

Reviews.Title: “A fun getaway !”
Reviews.Author: Ellemay
Reviews.Content: We decided to book this hotel due to the fact we wanted to be outside Waikiki and hopefully be close to a body surfing beach on the North Shore. Hotels are limited on this stretch of coastline and on their webpage; the hotel seemed to offer everything to suit our requirements. Check-in – We arrived early due to our flight from Australia and our room was ready and waiting for us. Staff were happy and efficient at reception. Room – Our room 550 was called a deluxe ocean view room and had gorgeous direct ocean views were we spent many hours meismerized by the movement of the waves breaking along the coastline. We were fortunate to watch a few whales pass by, unnoticed by many. The room was spacious with a king size bed, TV Cabinet, working desk and a large balcony attached with an outdoor dining set. Bathroom – Standard size with shower over bath, toiletries were also generously supplied. Another walk-in dressing room with excellent make-up mirrors, vanity unit, and mini bar (no contents) safe and coffee machine neatly placed on a trolley. Restaurants – We dined at 21, which is the fine dining restaurant, which has fabulous views of the ocean. The food was excellent and staff extremely attentive but we thought it to be very expensive. Another evening we dined at the beach café, which offered a sufficient menu with a good wine list. Breakfast we thought was very ordinary and badly organized. Overall, we thought the food to be above average although expensive. Facilities- The resort offers numerous water activities to keep one very amused. The lagoon beach is extremely safe for families; however, it had no waves, which was a disappointment for us. Luckily, we had a car and drove down the coastline to find some more suitable beaches for body surfing. The swimming pool seemed large with plenty of deck chairs overlooking the gorgeous beach. Surfboard lessons are available with the excellent sets rolling continuously close to the edge of the headland but not suited for swimmers. Overall – We had a lovely relaxing holiday and we loved our ocean view room. The hotel could do with a new face-lift but it is certainly adequate located on prime beachfront. There are clothes shops but no real supermarket for buying self-catering items An ATM machine is located next door to the reception. We have given the hotel a 5 star rating due to the prime beachfront location with its lovely surroundings. It takes approximately one hour to drive from the airport to the resort.

Reviews.Title: “Stay in the COTTAGES!!”
Reviews.Author: Scraggles
Reviews.Content: My family and I stayed at the Turtle Bay in the Cottages and I'm so thrilled we did not stay in hotel as reported by others it is dated and rooms worn and small. The cottages have their own concerige and staff with impecabble service quality. With a huge Lanai and fresh fruit delivered daily. I think the price was $ 200 more than a premium Rm and we decided our Dream trip to Hawaii was worth the splurge. The North Shore is secluded with little to offer in entertainment however WaiKiki is only an hour drive away. We were ROBBED on the Eastern part of the Island. Our rental car was broken into and all our Video/Cameras were stolen, do beware and NEVER leave anything unattended. The policeman said the locals WATCH/MONITOR tourists closely and routinely smash a car window grad what is visible and leave the area . We did not let this dampen our spirits or hawaiian experience. We had downloaded all our videos/pictures the night before and it happened the day before our deparure.

Reviews.Title: “Had a great time at Turtle Bay”
Reviews.Author: plum11
Reviews.Content: My husband and I recently went to Hawaii to celebrate our anniversary. We were married on Maui but did not visit Oahu on that trip so decided to go this time. We originally had booked a hotel at Hotel Renew (see other review) on Waikiki Beach. Waikiki was not for us. If you're looking for busy, and shopping, this is your place. Envision Las Vegas Strip on a beach. Anyhow, this all leads to us checking out and driving the the North Shore, with no reservations. We arrived at Turtle Bay, and told Sonja our story. Know that if you want to stay at the North Shore, Turtle Bay is pretty much it, unless you find a house to rent. Anyhow, fortunately for us, they had vacancy, as we did not call ahead. We were originally quoted a room of $330/night, and when we grimaced, she said "oh, wait a minute" and furiously typed for 5 minutes and found us a deluxe ocean view room for $200/night. You should know this is NOT a new hotel. If your looking for a sparkling new room with a flat screen and fancy surroundings, it is not here. However, you will find spacious rooms, large bathroom which is well kept and clean. They even have cotton balls and Q-tips in the bathroom. There is a refrigerator in the room. As I said,we had an ocean front room which was wonderful, We could see the whales and the surfers from our balcony. All the staff was fantastic! Everyone we dealt with was friendly and knowledgeable, and seemed to enjoy their job. The pool is very nice, not a small area but not huge. It has a great tiki type bar, with very friendly bartenders. We did not eat there, so I don't know about the food. It was very busy. I had a hard time finding a chair on one day. There are several restaurants on site, and there are several other good places to eat on the North Shore, but you have to drive about 20 minutes to get to them. Unfortunately, the restaurants weren't the highlight of the trip. We love to go to eat and try new places, and even though the restaurants weren't my favorite, I would definately stay here again. We ate the always overpriced breakfast buffet, and while the service was great, the food was not. Much better to go to Ted's Bakery (which is about a 10 minute drive and a local favorite) 21, their $$$ restaurant, was very good, but it is quite expensive. Ono was a mixed batch for us. We ate their twice and had 2 out of 4 great meals, and 2 out of 4 okay meals. The golf course restaurant , I think it was Lei Lei's was great, even though they screwed up my husband's steak 2 times before they got it right. The 3rd time was a charm! Had a pizza from the bar, which was great! It was late, and it was $26, but it was good! Turtle Bay is laid out very well. You can walk around the resort, and they have a beach area as well as the pool area. They have an excellent fitness center as far as hotel fitness centers go, but it also was busy. They also have a spa, but we did not use the services there. Surf lessons are also available,. Overall, we had a great time at Turtle Bay! We loved the North Shore. Everyone is laid back and friendly there, and while it can get busy in the town up there, it's nothing like the mayhem at Waikiki. We played both golf courses. The Palmer course was fantastic! Beautifully maintained, and challanging. The Fazio course....well the front nine is not worth playing. Flat with no challange. However, the back nine is nice. They maintain the back 9 like they do the Palmer course. Apparently, both courses are about to undergo a complete makeover. Could the resort use some updating? Yes. But it was clean, and friendly and the views are spectacular! Leave Waikiki and find other parts of Hawai!! I

Reviews.Title: “Good Times at Turtle Bay.”
Reviews.Author: hotgravy
Reviews.Content: I stayed two nights at Turtle Bay back at the end of September 2007 on my way to Maui. Went there to watch my girlfriend compete in the Miss Hawaiian Tropic International Model Search. I had to book my room at the last minute and was given amazing service over the phone by the wonderful folks at Turtle Bay. They really helped me out on short notice. Room was nice. The Sharper Image radio was set to special music that just gave you that feel of the islands. Very nice touch. Room view was amazing as you can see in the photos. Grounds were beautiful. I didn't really travel around outside the resort since I was there to watch the pageant and special Hawaiian Tropic luau. The bar area was great and the food out by the pool area was good too. It does get pretty windy here and the surf is constant. Saw a lot of surfers both days. The resort is on the North Shore so the shuttle from Honolulu took about an hour. But the drive is nice and the scenery is breathtaking! Again, I was only there two nights and was only there for an event and stop over for Maui but I had a great time just sitting by the pool and enjoying the scenery!

Reviews.Title: “Absolutley Beautiful”
Reviews.Author: krissssyg
Reviews.Content: Staying on the North Shore was the best decision by far once we pulled into Turtle Bay the day we arrived! Your far enough away from Waikiki and Honolulu tourists, but still close enough to get there in less than an hour if you have a car. Turtle Bay is breathtaking, hidden on the northern peninsula with beautiful scenery that I have ever seen. we arrived off our plane with lei's and went to tpick up our rental car, which you really need to get around Oahu. We spent ten days there and loved it. It has 6 restaurants at the resort, outside bar, relaxing spa, surfboard/bike/bookey board rentals, scuba diving lessons, two pools, one with a slide, and two hot tubs. You can surf right outside the hotel , just careful of the rocks , pretty shallow but you can surf right there with the sea turtles. The restaurants there can be pricey but it depends on what you eat. My boyfriend and I spent an average of $100 a night at the restaurants there and when we ate at 21 North it was a bit more expensive since its the top rated gourmet restaurant in Oahu. Lunch by the pool can cost anywhere between $25-30 easy. There is a Foodland grocery story on your way to Turtle Bay, and I suggest you stop and pick up a few things to have in your room to save some money. THey have complimentary coffee in your room and at night they do a turn down service with the oh so good macaroons wrapped in leaves. they forgot to turn it down two days in a row, so make sure you call down and have them deliver the cookies, its worth it. We were a little disappointed with the Lua at the resort. We were expecting to see the pig in the ground, but ended up having hte pork via buffet style and never saw the pig. the dancing and food was delicious, but we were expecting the pig! Make sure you go to Kualoa Ranch and do the 2 hour atv tour, best attractions there where you can see sets from Jurassic Park, Pearl Harbor, and Lost, etc and ride through the beautiful mountains. Def try jumping off the rock at Waimea Bay and venture into Honolulu to see the Pearl Harbor exhibit. Take a day or so and drive into Haliewa, cute little historic town about 15 minutes away with lots of shopping and great places to eat that are way more reasonable. the surf shop there is great, Surf & Sea, we did our scuba diving there and they were really nice. PIpeline was a sight to see but we found out that the big waves come in the winter, so we were a bit saddened we didnt the big kahunas but the waves were still big and I suggest you see it. Be sure to wear plenty of sun tan lotion and have a mai-tai. I would go back in a second! Beautiful beautiful island!!

Reviews.Title: “Villas are terrific!”
Reviews.Author: TBWYO
Reviews.Content: A villa is the only way to go. Pool, jacuzzi and just a 100 or so feet from the beach depending on the villa. There is a restaurant and bar located right on the beach. The beach and the views are very nice. My wife and I and our teenage daughters enjoyed are 4 nights there. We stayed in a 3 bedroom and it was spacious, clean and had great amenities. We had a problem with a broken umbrella when we arrived and it was immediately taken care of. Gina Olsen at Villas in the Tropics was great to work with and the villa was exactly as she told us it would be.

Reviews.Title: “Absolutely Horrible”
Reviews.Author: WelcomeBack4
Reviews.Content: First off, if you think you are going to enjoy the sun, forget it. This is the North Shore and at Turtle Bay the sun is behind you...which means you have to turn your chair away from the beach and look at the ugly grounds...The place is constantly windy. The bigger beach is for serious surfers and has a lot of lava, rocks, etc., on it. The mild beach is too mild and it happens to be a public beach. Our 3 bedroom ocean front villa was actually someone's condo. Nice mispresentation. The condo was very nice; the only saving grace at this resort. Condo had a great kitchen, but guess what??? Grocery store is a ways down the road. Would have been nice to know on our way in. The restaurants were completely sub par. At the beach restaurant I had to send a meal back because the salmon was so mushy/gross. If we hadn't thot to bring some dvds we would have gone crazy...no expanded cable/TV. It was like the hotel had nothing to do with the villas, excuse me, I mean condos. I called our travel agent 3 days into the trip and asked to come home early. What a colossal rip off, what an expensive joke on me. I hated this place.

Reviews.Title: “Turtle Bay-Overrated”
Reviews.Author: dw13
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a week at Turtle Bay. The grounds, and the overall property are very nice. The hotel is a dump. Our package included a free upgrade offered by the hotel at the time of booking. When we arrived, we were told this was based on availability, which of course, it was not. Our Premium room, included a balcony, the size of a bathtub, room for 2 people to stand on, but not sit on. When we were changed to the Deluxe room, 3 days later, we had a nice large balcony, overlooking the driveway and roof of the restaurant. When I complained, the manager, Aaron, told me many people really liked the view. The rooms are very dated and worn. They remind me of an old Motel 6, for $350 per night. The new cottages for an extra $150 per night, are beautiful. The fitness center has 2 treadmills, 1 of which was broken the entire week. The hotel's private beach was closed one full day to film a movie scene. The restaurants are OK, but $100 for breakfast for 2 adults and 2 teenagers? The location, as the only "resort" on the North Shore, is wonderful. But, by no means is this a 4 star resort.

Reviews.Title: “Great view, friendly people, relaxing vacation!”
Reviews.Author: lisalisa24
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Turtle Bay with our 2 kids - ages 11 and 12 - for Spring Break - and LOVED our vacation. It was very relaxing; and a nice getaway for our family. If you want a relaxing vacation - then go to Turtle Bay - the North Shore is like a different island than the crazy congestion that you'll experience in Waikiki Beach. The view is magnificent - ocean views from every room - and we enjoyed coming back from the beach and opening our door to listen to the ocean every day. Our room was kept immacutely clean. While it is true that the hotel room decor could be updated - the rooms are clean and the bathrooms are spacious - not to mention that we weren't in our rooms that often!! The North Shore offers the big waves, Haleiwa - great shopping and good food, the Shrimp Trucks, great beaches - what more could you want? If you want a REAL vacation - a chance to read your book, snorkel in the bay - see a few sea turtles and lots of fish, and really relax - then GO to Turtle Bay.

Reviews.Title: “Bad Experience”
Reviews.Author: LPPTraveller
Reviews.Content: Ok, before I explain how bad of a time I had, I will comment on a few good things: I stayed at the turtle bay hilton for 3 nights beginning Dec 4th. When we arrived, the bell captain was very friendly and showed us to our room which had a beautiful oceanfront view. The room was decent size but seemed a bit worn for the price. We ate at the expensive restaurant in the hotel (can't remember the name now). The food and service were and waiter were good. The BAD: Before we arrived at the hotel, we had heard locals talking in town that they were expecting a huge storm that night. However, I didn't hear anything from management of the hotel warning guests, and the wind appeared to be calm when we arrived. That night, a massive storm (probably in years) hit and we had water coming into our room as the sliding glass door for some reason is not watersealed at the top. I called the front desk and asked them to send maintenance up. However, 5 minutes later, power went down in the entire resort, so of course maintenance never came. The next morning, we didn't receive any info from management explaining what was going on. I tried asking the front desk, but they basically had a skeleton crew working who was just as uniformed as the rest of us. I explained about the water leakage and they said they would send maintenance but again they never came. She said when she called maintenance that they were aware that certain side of the building has water that comes in. I found it odd that they seemed unconcerned about any water/mildew damage as a result. The front desk didn't know when power was going to be up and they said as a result all the restaurants were closed except they had one buffet open, so we really had no choice but to eat there. The buffet was mainly cold cuts/bread/water/a few hot dishes and a few desserts. However, I thought it shocking that management was charing $17 per guest when they should have just given the food for free given what a bad experience the guests were going through and the limited food/drink. I felt like management was taking advantage of the guests not having any other place to go. When I took the elevator down to the lower level, there was one letter posted from management about the storm and power outage but again no details. I just find it odd in the age of cell phones, that management couldn't have called a news station and provided info that they posted in the lobby for guests to be informed. In addition, when I went back to the room, the water was cold in the shower. Again I asked the front desk and they said it had to do with the power outage, but that didn't make sense since they use gas to powere the hot water. Anyhow, so I had a cold shower and had to air dry my hair. I also asked if they were going to be passing out flashlights and they said they would. Well, they didn't and as it got dark, I had to call housekeeping to get flashlights. Again, I felt like guests were completely on their own to fend for themselves. Well, power finally came on at 8pm at night, thank god. Anyhow, it was a horrible experience, and the next day, there was a letter from management posted at the elevator that didn't really apologize for anything, just explained that we had survived the power outage. To make things worse, when we checked out, they tried to charge us the $20 resort fee. I explained to them, that I had booked through hotels.com and was told the price I paid included everything and was also told this upon check in. They said they needed my credit card only for incidentals yet they were now trying to charge me. I asked why I should be charged when it was so windy outside that we couldn't use the resort amenities and the power was out in the room so the safe/coffee machine could not be used. Finally, he agreed to charge me for half. I explained I shouldn't even have to pay for the 1st night due to the water coming in the room and he said I have to talk to hotels.com about that. I just couldn't believe how cheap the resort was and how in a crisis, management is non-existent and completely lacking any plan or customer service skills. I plan to write a formal letter to hilton corporation about the experience.

Reviews.Title: “A fabulous Place to Vacation!”
Reviews.Author: sedonagirl99
Reviews.Content: Just got back from a ten day Hawaii vacation, spending six nights at the Turtle Bay resort, and I absolutely loved my experience there! I booked a king ocean front room on the resort's website and paid $237 -- $243 per night (the higher rate for Fri & Sat). I found the room comfortably large but felt the furnishings were very ordinary -- not that it mattered. From the small juliet balcony of Room 351, I had a breath-taking view that overlooked the tropical grounds of the resort, public beach areas, nearby mountains and the endless crashing waves. I slept with the balcony door open so I could hear the sound of the surf --- I can't remember when I have slept so deeply and peacefully. A gentle sunset greeted me every morning. Mornings on the balcony were pleasant but the winds that came in the afternoons made it a bit chilly to sit out there without long sleeves. But, from my balcony, I saw a whale break the surface of the water in the near distance and that was truly exciting! I ate at all the resort's restaurants (with the exception of Lei Lei's) and very much enjoyed the food. I laughably budgeted $50 per day for meals but was at least $30-$50 off that amount if I wanted to eat three meals a day. I found most restaurant employees to be friendly and helpful, with the exception of a couple of servers at Hang Ten by the pool, when it got really busy during lunch and at sunset. Since I was traveling solo (an oddity in Hawaii, I discovered), I sometimes felt like I got second-level treatment, especially by male servers. However, I especially want to compliment the Bay Club, which I think is one of the more over-looked hospitality spaces. The service was excellent, the food a little lighter fare and the bartenders were the best in the hotel! I visited the spa on two occasions -- once for a lomi lomi massage and the other time for a pinapple pedicure. Both treatments were enjoyable but I consider the spa itself to be unimpressive. Coming from Aizona, I've visited some of the best spas in Scottsdale and Sedona and this one didn't measure up. Also, the spa charges an 18% service charge and I couldn't get a clear answer from the spa receptionists about how much of that went to the therapists. Fortunately, the young woman who gave me my massage told me the split is 15% to therapist and 3% overhead to the spa itself. One reason I picked Turtle Bay was for the horse-back riding. I went on the 50-minute trail ride ($50), the 80-minute evening ride ($80), and a private 7:30 am ride ($100) where I got to trot and lope when appropriate. I would definitely recommend the latter two rides -- they were great fun and I got to see a lot of different landscapes. And I think the regular trail ride probably is the best choice for inexperienced riders. Kudos to the house-keeping staff who were always friendly and very sensitive to guests' schedules. When I was taking a nap a couple of afternoons, they honored the do-not-disturb sign on my door and left a card under the door telling me to call when I was ready to have my room cleaned. I noticed there was staff on the floor as late as 9pm -- unusual in most hotels I've stayed at. My floor had three washers and dryers in a room by the ice-maker. That was very convenient but a little pricey. $2.50 each for the washer and dryer and $1 each for detergent and fabric softener if you didn't bring your own. Even so, the machines were very busy, especially at night. I have only two minor complaints about my stay: (1) I had some difficulty accessing yahoo email on the computers in the business office -- it had something to do with the filtering system that the hotel uses and I found the whole issue quite irritating, and (2) unless you used valet parking, it was quite a hike to the parking lot if you were carrying anything heavy or awkward -- plus, someone ripped the canvas on the convertible top of my rental car and I have no idea what the car rental company may charge me for that little bit of vandalism. I hope that Turtle Bay's proposed future development is squashed because I think the area is developed sufficiently now and would hate to see some of forests where I went horse-back riding disappear. The governor has proposed that the state buy the property and I can't help but wonder what that might mean as far as the hotel is concerned. We all know what kind of quality service governments tend to offer, or how disappointing contracted-out services can be. Oh well, I'm sure my next visit to the Turtle Bay Resort will happen well before any of those political issues are laid to rest. I can hardly wait to return!

Reviews.Title: “Excellent,relaxing hotel”
Reviews.Author: MTMx2
Reviews.Content: We stayed here late Feb early March for a week, loved it! All the hotel staff was very friendly, from the front desk to housekeeping to the breakfast buffet staff( breakfast was wonderful). Room was clean, comfy bed, nice bathroom,nice view. 2 pools, warm, hot tub -too hot for me. The ocean was wild,huge waves, there is a calm beach which is ok for snorkeling. We rented a car for the week(National car company at Airport-very efficient- got a great deal thru travel agent) which was great,there is alot to see on Ohau.We went to Pearl Harbor, hiked Diamond Head, shopped Waikiki,swam with sharks,checked out alot of beaches. ... Ate at Giovanni's shrimp truck which was delicious We had dinner once at the hotel ( golf course), at Lei Lei's which was excellent..Our week at Turtle Bay was probably our best vacation so far, would love to go back, it was a long plane ride however, but we were ready for that. Just know when you are coming from the east coast, it is LONG but worth it!

Reviews.Title: “It was ok... great view but otherwise just ok.”
Reviews.Author: seattletocincy
Reviews.Content: We just got home from our 5 night stay. Views are amazing but everything else was just okay. Our second day there we found a live roach in the bed so they moved us to another room... That room had ants in the fridge. So, they moved us again. I wasn't expecting to be dealing with a pest problem at a 4 star resort and it certainly put a damper on the trip - I didn't sleep well the rest of our time there. Husband thought the mattresses were uncomfortable. The bathrooms need updating and the rooms could use a fresh coat of paint. We found this to be the case in all 3 of the rooms we saw. Overall it is a nice resort with an amazing view and water access. But, the place just seems dated (for the price) and could use a makeover - other than the new throw pillows and comforters.

Reviews.Title: “Tutle Bay was Super!”
Reviews.Author: RachelWEdmontonABCA
Reviews.Content: My husband and I had a completely wonderful 1 week stay at Turtle Bay in Feb 08. The resort is everything one imagines a Hawaiian destination to be - secluded, tropical, deserted beaches, big waves, cool ocean breezes, wonderful friendly people. We got all our information from the fabulous Turtle Bay Report website (after readings reviews here) and contacted the resort by phone to make our reservations. We have stayed in some top-drawer places and Turtle Bay rates near the top for service and ambiance. Check-in is arduous, but with such a beautiful atmosphere and people that are genuinely trying to help you, one can't stay annoyed for very long. Darn, we just had to go to Ola's and have margarita's on the beach until our room was ready - how bad can things get. Mahalo!

Reviews.Title: “A solid B+ resort”
Reviews.Author: TR-Den
Reviews.Content: Pros: Secluded location Good golf, but very windy (in April) Nice pool Easy access to the islands more remote locations Lots of free parking Best food at the resort is at the Golf Shop Lots of walking trails around the property Easy access to the beach Nice staff Cons: RESORT FEE – I hate them! Rooms have been updated, but lack any real luster and still feel dated Very windy! (Again in April) There is little to nothing to eat within a 30 minute drive of the resort Summary: If you are looking for ultimate seclusion, with the addition of easy access to Golf, then Turtle Bay is perfect. I do feel that other resorts like the 4 Seasons Maui, Grand Wailea Maui, and JW Marriott on the other side of the Island offer an experience more on par with what you expect at a resort such as this. I don’t regret staying here, but would not go back given all the other phenomenal choices in Hawaii.

Reviews.Title: “Spectacular views and a Nice Hotel”
Reviews.Author: San Diego is best
Reviews.Content: We booked our visit thru Costco Travel, getting a lei greeting, rental car and 4 nights at Turtle Bay. The room rate worked out to be around $250/night. A business associate in Honolulu advised us we'd be happy at that price; the complaints seem to be from people paying much more than that. We enjoyed our 4 night stay at Turtle Bay very much. We arrived at Honolulu airport and picked up a rental car for the drive out to the North Shore, stopping at Costco for supplies (just off H-2). We also stopped in Haleiwa for snacks, since it was on the way. Once arriving at the resort, we were warmly greeted by the valet and bell staff. (It's $10/day to valet park. Self-parking is no charge and the lot is not that far from the hotel.) The front desk staff were also friendly and welcoming. We reserved a deluxe oceanfront king room and were assigned room 603 (East Tower, top floor, 2nd room from the elevator). We thought we would have a full balcony, but the balcony was barely big enough for the 2 chairs that were there. We noticed other rooms with larger chairs & larger balconies. We were going to request a room change, but the view was so spectacular,looking over the swimming beach, that we decided to stay where we were. We could hear the waves crashing even up 6 floors and slept with the sliding door open. Plus, we took some amazing sunrise photos, and saw whales playing out in the ocean every afternoon. The room itself was clean & nicely decorated, large bathroom, a separate sink and large closet in the dressing area, which also had a small refrigerator, safe and coffee maker. We noticed the plaster on the ceiling was "bubbled" in a few places (maybe a leak or maybe from too many visitors leaving the sliding door open?) We were very comfortable. We had breakfast in the Palm Terrace, but ordered from the menu and not the $24 buffet. The food looked great but we would have been hard-pressed to eat $24 worth of food to make it worth our while. Dinner at Ola's on the beach was delicious as was lunch and dinners at Lei Lei's on the golf course (with the best service of any of the places, however, no view). We also had drinks and lunch at the Hang Ten bar by the pool. Again, no complaints. There is a controversy between the resort and the governor, who wants to take over the 880 acres, which has resulted in some travel booking sites not to carry the resort on their inventory. Maybe the resort will offer some bargain rates to lure back visitors. Turtle Bay is a terrific place to just relax, away from the crowds and "hustle & bustle" of Waikiki, for the right price. Check it out!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing honeymoon at Turtle Bay”
Reviews.Author: sir_snorksalot
Reviews.Content: We went to Turtle Bay and had an amazing honey moon. The hotel and grounds were beautiful, and the staff very eager to please. Our room was perfect, and very clean. The restaurants at Turtle Bay were amazing. Seriously, all of them, but especially 21 Degrees North and Ola. Everything also seemed reasonably priced, which I didn't expect at a resort. The little lagoon was fabulous for both sunbathing, swimming, and especially snorkeling (lots of corral, cool fish, and even an eel). Best of all, it was never crowded. We rented a car, and were able to see a lot of the island, eat at other restaurants, and explore other beaches, which were also amazing. But we could easily have spent all of our time there. In short, perfect honeymoon.

Reviews.Title: “Great for couples”
Reviews.Author: Sam_and_Grant
Reviews.Content: We got a web deal for this hotel and paid about US$300 for the night as a "treat" for ourselves, which is quite pricey by our standards. But it was worth every cent. Beautiful location, lots of little touches to make your stay that extra little bit special (free postcards, Hawaiian music playing when you enter the room. Amazing sunset. Good food and drinks. Just a great place to stay, particularly when you have had a long day travelling and all you want to do is crash at a nice resort. Thanks Turtle Bay!

Reviews.Title: “Very Good Choice”
Reviews.Author: mare592
Reviews.Content: My husband is an avid golfer, and we like the quiet life of the North Shore. I never saw a "bad" beach on Oahu; in my opinion, they have some of the best beaches anywhere. We stayed in the Ocean Front Cottages for 4 nights. We were in building 110, just feet from the beach. We had a hammock right outside our room. The room was clean and spacious. I loved the wood floors. The bed was firm and comfy, and the pillows semi flat, which I prefer. The TV was small, but it was OK. The bathroom was luxurious and spacious. I loved the shower, and the separate toilet was nice. There was some rust from hard water on the sink. Other than that, I found no flaws. We had a lot of traffic going thru the back yard from other cottage and beach goers. I liked keeping all the blinds open with the screens, listening to the waves and letting in fresh air, so everyone could easily see in our room. At night we closed the door and curtains. The parking here was a bit of a problem. We had to park across the street several lots away due to no parking spaces available a couple of times. We ate at the golf course several times, and found it to be good and reasonable compared to Hawaii standards. Expensive food and daily resort fees of $20 is a common thread in Hawaii. We found the breakfast buffet to be barely OK. For what you paid, it's not worth it. We golfed the 2 courses, and found them to be nice but disappointing. We expected ocean views, and only one hole actually had an ocean view on the green. The rest of the places we golfed had ocean views on almost every hole. We did the horseback ride (90 minutes @ a walk, great for green cowpokes) with another couple, and enjoyed it. Cost is $80 each. The island of Oahu has a lot of poverty and some deplorable conditions, both of which you'll see on your trip from the airport as you arrive to Turtle Bay. This island has the pipeline for surfers, some of the best surfing anywhere, so be prepared for cars parked along the roads, and a lot of locals, kids, hippies, tourists and riffraff. The locals play on weekends, too, so be prepared for crowds. We did the Memorial on Sat. morning, arriving @ 7 am, and had to wait in line about 45min. It opens @ 7:30. There are cruise ship tours arriving at about 7:15 or so by bus load. The actual tour took about 3 hours. We did the Arizona and Missouri. This is not to be missed in my opinion. Bring your kleenex. We saw no whales (I'm an avid whale watcher) but saw hundreds in Maui after we left. The surf was high and rough, so they're hard to spot @ Turtle Bay. We took a couple of island drives in our jeep. We didn't have the top off the jeep the whole time due to rain. One of our tee times was canceled due to heavy rain. The conciarge service was fantastic. Our calls were returned within 3 minutes each time we required their services. We got spoiled with the filled ice twice a day, cookies on our pillow every night (except the first night???) and fresh fruit daily. The toiletries were OK. I'm pretty picky; I like my own from home. I'm not into fruit smells or peppermint. I also never used the tub, so I cannot comment on this. I would definitely stay here again, but I don't think we'll do Oahu anytime soon.

Reviews.Title: “If I paid extra for it then it was amazing.”
Reviews.Author: avonlee16
Reviews.Content: Turtle Bay was better than the average resort but I still only gave it 4 stars for a few reasons. 1) I paid $340 for my room (with a kamaaina discount might I add) and my room was small. Maybe 400 square feet? And the carpet had stains. Large, dark stains. Strike one. 2) When booking into a resort like this I am expecting an amazing bathroom. Not so much. Average shower head. And run of the mill shampoo and lotion. Hhhmmm. I booked myself into Spa Luana for a massage and a facial. This was a great idea. The spa was amazing. Massage was top notch. The therepist went over an hour which was fine by me and I had use of the wonderful locker room for as long as I wanted. Steam room, showers and meditation area.
