This redeemed Turtle Bay huge amounts. I readied myself for dinner and we ate at 21 degrees north, the fine dining restaurant at Turtle Bay. Again the resort redeemed itself. We had the chef's pairing where each course is paired with wine. Wonderful! As it should be for $110 per person. The moral is: if extra money was paid for it then very above average. But in itself the rooms were not great. At least mine. The lobby was not great. The pool was not fantastic. I was looking for fantastic. And my one night stay cost $796.

Reviews.Title: “Loved Turtle Bay Resort”
Reviews.Author: TexasKBEE
Reviews.Content: My husband and I just celebrated our 50th wedding anniversary with a trip to Oahu where we stayed at the wonderful Turtle Bay Resort on the North Shore. We chose an ocean front king room and we were rewarded with a great view of the ocean from a small balcony. The higher priced deluxe ocean front rooms overlooked both ocean and pool area and had a larger balcony, but we were not at all disappointed with our choice. The room was huge, spotlessly clean and attractively decorated. Amenities included a small fridge, coffee maker, iron, etc. We had a lovely dinner at the hotel restaurant, 21 Degrees North, where we were given a window table and presented with a complimentary dessert honoring our anniversary. We later dined at another of their restaurants, Ola, which is equally good, and which is situated right on the beach. We also had lunch at both Lei Lei's at the golf shop and Hang Ten bar at the pool. All the food was tasty and well presented, although one should be aware that everything in Hawaii is more expensive than on the mainland. Since we aren't big breakfast eaters, we bought fruit, yogurt and juice at the nearby Foodland, stored it in the fridge, and avoided the pricey breakfast buffet. We also enjoyed the Friday night luau which, unfortunately, had to be brought indoors because of showers. The entertainment was excellent although the buffet dinner was mediocre. Still, the $85 pp tickets were worth it to us. The resort itself has two professional golf courses, the Arnold Palmer on which championship tournaments are played, and the Fazio course which is a bit more forgiving and which my husband enjoyed thoroughly. In addition, we walked several marked trails and later watched a glorious sunset over the water from just outside the Sunset Room. Besides the nice pool for swimming and/or lounging, there is access to the ocean where one can surf right at the resort. Outside the resort, just a few miles away, are the world famous surfing areas where the very big waves come in during the winter. Honolulu is just over an hour away by car -- a little more during rush hours -- so we were able to go there to visit the Arizona Memorial, the Missouri, and Waikiki Beach. We purchased a package from Orbitz, giving us 5 nights at the resort and a mid-size car (upgraded to a full size by Alamo) for 5 days, for a total of $1388, or approximately $278 per day for room and car. Frankly, I would hesitate to pay rack rate for the room which is in the $300+ range, but packages seem to be available from several sources. Turtle Bay Resort is a gorgeous piece of property set in Hawaiian paradise, with staff' that are friendly and eager to assist -- always with a smile and an "Aloha." I highly recommend Turtle Bay Resort for travelers of all ages.

Reviews.Title: “Real Hawaii”
Reviews.Author: beachme82
Reviews.Content: If you're coming to the North Shore, Turtle Bay is pretty much the only option. Out on a windy point in the rural North Shore, the hotel and its many restaurants sit on an expansive property with amazing ocean views. Turtle Bay Resort is not a five star luxury resort, so don't be fooled when you book your stay. It's missing a few things, but if you can overlook some minor faults, you'll be rewarded with a relaxing stay on the North Shore. The property is incredible and the rooms are spacious, clean and well-decorated. Watch out - the resort charges a $20 per day "resort fee" that covers parking, wireless internet and snorkeling. They don't inform you of the fee when you check in, it only says on a printed card in your room that you will be charged a "modest fee" each day. The best part about the resort is the miles of walking trails along beautiful untouched beaches. A morning walk with a cup of Kona coffee in hand is a great way to start the day. The best place to "beach yourself" is the sandy beach on a protected cove adjacent to the hotel. The beach is small, but the cove has a soft, sandy bottom and is great for swimming. While beautiful, the resort's location makes the property very windy. The pool area was so windy we couldn't lay by the pool or enjoy a drink/food at the poolside bar. Eating at the resort can be a little challenging. There are several restaurants that serve expensive food that doesn't vary too much between restaurants. Expect to pay between $20-$50 per entree, no matter what you order. Ola, by the beach, is the best bet. Close to the crashing surf, the atmosphere far exceeds that of the resort's other restaurants. Lei Lei's, by the golf course, is also good. Again, both places are expensive. To save money, you can shop at the nearby Foodland grocery store (a few miles down the road in Sunset Beach) and stock your fridge with breakfast and lunch snacks. If you want a short drive to dinner, the shrimp shacks in Kahuku are amazing. The dinner is messy - and the meal is prepared in a questionable old truck - but it's worth it. Try Giovanni's Original White Shrimp Truck. A longer drive - about 25 minutes away in Halewia - there are a lot more restaurants and shops.

Reviews.Title: “DIsappointed in Turtle Bayl”
Reviews.Author: sarabeth715
Reviews.Content: My sister and I stayed two nights at the resort and were disappointed in the quality of the rooms.There was no information in our room to tell about restaurants or activities at the resort or where things were located at the resort. As we were checking out we were told the card our keys came in opened up for a display of the property. A little bit late, too bad it wasn't explained at check-in. My sister called the conceirge to request info on a helicopter ride available on the property and glider flight off the property. The concierge called her back saying both were filled up. My sister isn't dissuaded that easily and called both places and got exactly what she wanted. WE ate dinner one night at 21 North on their property and were disappoined with the food and cost. The next night we ate at Ola's ( I think thats what it was called) next door to the resort. Better food and prices and our table was actually in the sand, that was great. The views from the room were wonderful, the best part of the resort.

Reviews.Title: “The best of Turtle Bay Resort”
Reviews.Author: DebRandy
Reviews.Content: We booked our vacation to Turtle Bay Resort through our Airlines Vacation plan. It was our first trip to Hawaii so we decided to upgrade to a cottage room which made the price about $600 per night (including the resort fee) but it was so worth it. The Hotel was nice but we wanted a quite get away. Accomodations: The cottage was beautiful and since the cottages are a recent addition in good condition. Photos included of the cottage 141 which is furthest from the hotel. We called a week in advance of our arival and requested our room be close to the water and far from the hotel and received exactly that. The room had a king size bed which was quite comfortable, light weight down comforter, plenty of feather bed pillows. Closet was well stocked with more pillows (hyop alergenic) and more blankets which were great for use in the hammock right out side the room. Robes and slippers and an inroom safe. Free wifi, (my computer hooked up effortlessly). Bathroom was well done, Very clean and spacious, plenty of towels in all sizes, lighted mirror, hair dryer and plenty of outlets for phone chargers and camera chargers. Thow open the large slider doors and let the sound of waves sooth your spirit. Lanai has ocean view, chairs, rocker and table for outdoor relaxation and a hammock is just a few feet away with ocean view. Staff: Service was excellent, from the concierge who greeted us and explained the services we would receive. Maid service daily, early newspaper, turn down service at night, which included home made cookie snacks wrapped in coconut leaves (nice touch), fresh ice twice a day and fruit of the day, usually exotic fruit. Room service was excellent all but one night (our last and a Friday night before a big golf tournament when it was 45 minutes late). The breakfast buffet was good its cheaper to order off the menu but it still comes from the buffett, Ola's excellent, Palm terrace good, We skipped 21 and Lei lei's based on reviews we read here. Location: The North shore can't be beat. Honolulu was big city noisy and stress full. The drive to the North shore is refreshing and what Oahu is all about. Beatuiful clean beaches, great waves. We rented a car as part of the vacation package and drove around the island twice. It's easy to get around, people are friendly and the food is great no matter where you go. Oahu is a great adventure and Turtle bay is a great as a home base for your travels. Aloaha!

Reviews.Title: “North Shore Oahu -Turtle Bay Resort - Tropical Paradise!”
Reviews.Author: GOPARADISE
Reviews.Content: Our family loved our recent trip to Oahu, on the North Shore we stayed at the TURTLE BAY RESORT! It was heavenly, the beauty was breath-taking! Bring your sun screen and water toys since you can easily do the beach and the 5 pools for hours! Bring a case of water and a LOT of snacks to the resort if you stop at Costco, you will be glad you have them. If you have babies, toddlers bring swim diapers since they have a little keiki pool just for them! We were able to balance a lot of family time as well as some more romantic date time by hiring an in room babysitter. GREAT IDEA if you plan to travel with little kids, since the Resorts childcare program only takes kids over 5. We found "Miss Mary" on Craigslist, Hawaii, under CHILDCARE, she advertises under keywords " I come to You! Childcare, she was great and really made the time she spent with our 2 boys, 1.5 and 4, really fun and very memorable for them, which allowed us to have some well appreciate time alone together, we ended up hiring her 4 times in our week there the kids really just had a blast too. We had a really romantic dinner with sunset at the 21 Degree North restaurant and were even able to hike to the top of Diamond Head without the kids, it was just WONDERFUL to get to feel like we were "on a date" in Paradise ! We also did the shark cage dive it was really exciting and thrilling, well worth the money too!

Reviews.Title: “True Paradise”
Reviews.Author: bsoxfan
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Turtle Bay resort in October 2007. It was an absolutely perfect stay. We had never been to Hawaii before and friends of our recommended Turtle Bay to us. We arrived on a Saturday evening after 12 hours of flight time. The drive up to the North Shore was beautiful. After you pass Haleiwa, you start to see the ocean on your left. Beautiful views as the sun was beginning to set. We arrived at Turtle Bay and the view in the lobby was wonderful. They have huge glass windows that overlook the beach. I had read prior postings that the views are much better from the higher floors. Unfortunately I forgot about this upon check-in and we were given a room on the second floor. The view from the room wasn't great so I called down to the front desk and asked if we could switch to a higher floor. They said they were sold out on Saturday night but would move us on Sunday. Sure enough, we received a phone call from the front desk Sunday afternoon saying we could move to a room on the 6th floor. We did and the view was amazing! The grounds of the hotel were beautiful and we enjoyed walking on the trails that they have. We also did a horseback ride at the hotel that was a lot of fun. A rental car is a must if you are staying on the North Shore so that you can go exploring. We went to the Waimea Falls Audubon center one day which is about 15 minutes away. It's a nice walk up to a waterfall where you can go in for a swim. Beautiful flowers on the walk up and a very peaceful place. We also enjoyed Waimea Bay beach. Again, stunning views. We were there just as the high surf season was kicking off so the surf wasn't that big yet. The town of Haleiwa is also a great place to explore. We had lunch there a couple of days and did some shopping. We found the help at Turtle Bay to be awesome. Everyone was very friendly and helpful. The only issue is there are a lack of dining options in the area. You are pretty much limited to the hotel unless you want to drive to Haleiwa, about 20 minutes away. We did have lunch at the pool one day(good), dinner at Ola's(very good) and Lei Lei's (not so good). There is also a coffee stand in the lobby that is a great place to get coffee and muffins, pastries, etc in the morning. There is a Foodland supermarket 10 minutes away that will make sandwiches and has salads etc. so we picked up lunch there one day and brought it to the beach. Also picked up snacks there for the room. We went to Waikiki one day and couldn't believe how hectic it was. We were so glad that we chose to stay at Turtle Bay on the North Shore instead of hectic Waikiki. It was the best vacation that we have ever been on and we were so sad to leave. We can't wait to return there someday!

Reviews.Title: “Returned home last night. Rested and happy.”
Reviews.Author: Ruislip5826
Reviews.Content: As a family we love our trips to Hawaii. Over the years we have visited Maui - the Big Island and Kauai. But never stayed on Oahu. Fearing it's all Wakikiki - high rises and crowded beaches. (We can get that in Santa Monica, near where we live). We took a trip to England and Paris last summer and booked every hotel based on Trip advisor recommendations. This worked out beautifully. So I searched for remote Oahu hotels and avidly read about the Turtle Bay Resort. The reviews were mixed. Some felt very under-served and others seemed to love their visit. We contacted a friend who lived in Hawaii and she supported the positive reviews. We were very glad she did. We had a 6 night visit to a wonderfully unpretentious but very affable and fulfilling Hotel. We stayed in a beach front Cottage - with the surf just tens of feet from out front veranda. That alone was an escape. The Hotel is almost as far away from Honolulu as you can get. And despite having a fine golf course - a good spa and a very good range of restaurants. The location was totally escapist. Empty beaches to ramble away from the hotel core for miles. Service was friendly -- and didn't run on "island time". While there we also made a point of looking at three different room styles that the hotel offers in it's main 6 story building. While some reviewers had complained of poor quality - what we saw were renovated and very acceptable rooms. We would recommend the higher the better for view purposes. With or without balcony's is a cost change. But has a value. We hit winter wave season. Which meant the ocean views where spectacular. Nearby beaches had many surfers. The hotel had a small safe beach. While the others were too wild for swimming. But he hotels pool was wells sized. Our gold standard for Hawaii hotels has always been the Mani Lani Bay on the Big Island. An expensive but very cool spot, which we have been to at least 7 times. After our highly pleasurable visit the Turtle Bay Resort we've been converted and are likely to be repeat users.

Reviews.Title: “Our Honey Moon -the Good/Bad and Ugly”
Reviews.Author: JOLEANROOK
Reviews.Content: I orginally found this Hotel through trip advisor and we booked it for our honeymoon through Expedia. Oh boy do I have a lot to warn you about and brag about. First we rented a Pikaki Jr. Suite (apparently "Jr" means KIDS not smaller). So when we arrive for our HONEYMOON (which we had called ahead and let the hotel know that was our purpose for staying - hoping for a little extra service) we arrive to our room to find it VERY small and drab (big balcony though) with a stuffed animal on the bed (which you have to buy for $20!) Disapointed but feeling like there was nothing we ould do about it we began to get undressed (it's almost 11pm and we had an 8 hr flight) right in the middle of undressing house keeping WALKS RIGHT IN ON US. No knock, nothing. After they left I went to lock the door and I stepped on the carpet infront of the AC and it was SOAKED. I immediatly called the front desk and insisted they do something, "after all, it's our honeymoon." Promptly they agreed to move us and sent the bell boy up. The bell boy came, gave us the new room key and then walked away, he didn't even help us with our bags! When we finally found the other room - on our own, we went in... another Pikake Jr. suite.. but this one had a TINY balcony, much smaller than the last with barely enough room to fit 2 chairs. Very mad with the bellboy situation and now feeling like we got DOWNGRADED I called the desk again and the man was very kind and offered to move us yet again, adding "You won't be dissapointed." The bell boy comes, this time helps us, and leads us to "The best-view room in the hotel" Our new room was the "Maile" which is the 2nd best room there (2nd only to the Ali'l Presidential Suite". Now THIS was better. Same size bedroom but now we had an adjoining living room/dining room plus 2 bathrooms and 2 HUGE balconies. (This is what I had originally expected for paying nearly $500/night!) So there is the first part of our experience, horrible but a great end result.... moving on.... (OH, and since the hotel sits on a penninsula, every room has an ocean view) EXPENSES: This is a pricey hotel, and everything costs $, even the water in your room is $3/bottle if you choose to drink it. I recommend going to Wal-Mart (There is only 1 on the island) and buying your own drinks/snacks to stock the fridge with. (Also maybe your own shampoo since theirs is very drying.) DONT FORGET THERE IS A $20.00/DAY RESORT FEE. That's right, when you check out you will recieve a bill for $20 every day you were there (For us that ended up being $100!!!) This is suppose to cover self-parking, 1 snorkel rental per day for 1 hour, a newspaper, and wi-fi. You get charged this even if you do not use the services. Room service is extremely expensive, breakfast for two was $45. Dinner was $115 (and that was us trying to eat cheap.) The Turtle's Den is a better option for breakfast/snacks (It's a cart down in the lobby.) The Lobby is great, awesome view and beautiful decor. Don't buy postcards, the front desk will give you some for free and they will mail them (This is the only free thing you get!) 21 Degrees North, hoity toity resteraunt in the hotel, great for dinner - only $110 for two and that was us not trying to eat cheap; Reservations are REQUIRED. Lastly, I would take advantage of the 1 hr/day snorkel rental since you get charged for it anyway, we did and it really was neat on the beautiful Turtle Bay beaches... high tide kept us pretty close to shore though. DISASTER: We went December 2 and stayed a week, during which time a record breaking storm hit the island. Power went out @ the Resort for TWO DAYS!!! No AC, no nothin'. What sucked the worst was the first day the police would not let anyone travel b/c of powerlines in the road so we were stuck in the resort. The staff tried very hard to be helpful, but I think they could have done better. For example, with everyone stuck, no AC, no lights, you would think they would at least provide you food or drinks or knock off the resort fee...NO. (We eventually did get the resort fee knocked off one day but we had to argue with them a lot.) Since you had to eat their that day they did a buffet and all they had was food like breakfast : cereal, toast, coffee, eggs, bacon, juice, danishes, donuts (until they ran out) and lunch: beef scewers, fish/rice, sandwich stuff, rolls, coffee, water (until they ran out) and they charged us $30 for (2)brkfst, and $60 for (2) lunch!!!!! OUTRAGEOUS considering the circumstances!! The Humidity is awful when there is no AC so everyone tried to stay outside, but since this happened the last 2 days we were @ the resort it was not a pleasant memory. Neither was having to lug all our suitcases down the stair well 4 flights in the dark by ourselves. NORTHSHORE: This hotel is GREAT for a true Northshore experience, stunning views and unbeatable surroundings, but just expect to feel a little jyped on the price and level of service. We went into Honolulu/Waikiki and compared to other Hotels this one absolutely LOOKS more like Hawaii, everywhere else is SOOOO Touristy and you feel like you are in Japan, not Hawaii. NorthShore is considered "the country" so it is secluded and romantic, however if you have any events booked you will likely have to drive clear accross the island to Honolulu/Waikiki to do them. A CAR RENTAL IS A MUST!! We booked events through expedia like a dinner cruise (horrible, overbooked), a submarine tour (got canceled due to weather-refunded), a scuba catamaran (got canceled due to weather-refunded), and a luau - pretty cool-decent food - loooong show. There is not much to do in NorthShore, and the homes are delapatated, but the natural beauty is stunning -great place for waves too because it is the windiest point on the island. Great sand, Great clear/blue waters. Pearl Harbor is a must see, we were there on the anniversery of it - increadible (get there before 2, tours sell out). ALL AND ALL: I would not go back. We have stayed at many resorts and this one, were it not for the perfect location, would rank @ the very bottom. Catch 22, if we DID go back I would probably would stay here again, but only because the options are pretty limited. If you rule out turtle Beach talk to people who have been to other resorts there and find the best one possible - if it is less than 4 star it will be a DUMP as much of Oahu is now overpopulated, over-toured, dirty and over priced. MY pix are a true representation, some of the ones on the turtle bay website are NOT.

Reviews.Title: “Over Priced for a Place that was nice....in 1982”
Reviews.Author: Doctor_Pescado
Reviews.Content: Looking at the website we were psyched to get this place. However, for $400 a night this place was definitely not worth the money. We traveled up from Waikiki after the Honolulu Marathon as a treat since we have never been to North Shore. North Shore rocked, this place was someplace that my Dad might have been impressed by 20 years ago, which is also the last time they did any updating, renovating, or cleaning of the carpets. The halls look institutional with bare panels exposed and reception and a foyer that is Brady Bunch chic. Walking into our room it smelled of must and mildew. There was notable damage to the furniture and obvious water stains on the wall. The bathroom...was interesting. We complained about the room and were greeted by night supervisor by "Let's Go" as he walked us up the fire escape stirs to our new room. The new room was slightly better (no damage and must smell), but the way it was handled sucked. The manager did his best to appease us ($75 credit) and he was polite and apologetic, but that did not really change my impression nor my wife's impression of the place. They really need to spend a few bucks to upgrade this place and also train their staff as to how to behave in a luxury property.

Reviews.Title: “Lots of Money, No Service and No Hospitality”
Reviews.Author: sandysloop
Reviews.Content: Beautiful property, but you are made to feel like a wallet and not a guest! We stayed in a 3 bedroom villa which had a living,room dining room, kitchen, 2 baths and a good size balcony overlooking a small pool, hot tub and the ocean. I cannot fault the villa, it was both tastefully decorated and spotlessly clean. However, it was on the third floor and one person in our party was in a wheelchair. A good hotel would have put us on the ground floor. But worse, we had to unload our own luggage from our rental car, and drag it what seemed like miles to the elevator and then miles to our villa. At over 1200 a night, one expects better service. I was shocked. My daughter was married at their little chapel and I was late getting to the wedding because my hair appt took longer than expected. I rushed to the desk and asked them if they could take me to the chapel in one of their many golf carts sitting there...the peson I asked said no! Can you imagine!! He actually said there was no way to get there with the cart...but a pefectly appropriate cart path led right to it! Turtle Bay lacks the one thing that sets Hawaii apart from other sunny beach locations, friendly helpful people. This beautiful place totally lacks the charm and spirit of the Hawaiian people. We found that hospitality at a much less expensive hotel on Waikiki beach, where the hectic pace of the city could have turned the hotel into the cold uncaring place that sadly Turtle Bay is...front page news while we were there...Turtle Bay declared bankruptcy...no surprise...you just dont feel happy there...you feel like you could have just mailed them your wallet and left them alone. Hospitality? none.

Reviews.Title: “Enjoyable Stay at Turtle Bay”
Reviews.Author: Kvikk_Lunsj
Reviews.Content: My wife and I had a wonderful two night stay at Turtle Bay Resort in October 2007. The resort's principal draw is its location and it is, indeed, spectacular. The grounds are well maintained and there are a number of walking trails (although they are not well-marked). We booked our 3rd floor Deluxe guestroom through Hotwire for $258/night + resort fee and taxes...a nice discount off what the resort quoted me. (Although Hotwire does not reveal the name of the hotel until after you've committed to the purchase, in this instance it's easy to be confident that it will be Turtle Bay Resort because there are no other "4-star" hotels in Kahuku, Oahu! However, a cautionary note--if you book through Hotwire, Priceline, or a similar discounter, be sure to call the resort well before arrival and confirm your reservation details. I'm glad I did, because I learned that Turtle Bay expected us to arrive a week later than what we'd reserved. Fortunately, we were able to straighten that out before we got there. At least they admitted that it was their error and that the paperwork from Hotwire was correct.) Our room was spacious, and the bathroom was possibly the largest hotel bathroom I've seen. It's true, as others have mentioned, that the Deluxe guestrooms do have some wasted space--there would be plenty of room to add a loveseat/small sofa--but it wasn't an issue for us. The room was spotless clean and, unlike what some other reviewers have experienced, the furniture did not look weathered. In fact, we did not have any of the accomodation problems reported by some reviewers. The bathroom fixtures could have used some updating, but again it wasn't an issue for us. Based on earlier reviews we read here, we chose not to dine at Ola or at 21 Degrees North, and we avoided the overpriced breakfast buffet. Instead, we ate breakfast and dinner at Lei Lei's Bar & Grill at the golf course, less than a 5 minute stroll from the main resort building. The food there was excellent and fairly priced (especially relative to what Ola and 21 Degrees charge) and the service was attentive. Perhaps this is because, as we were told, Lei Lei's is located on the resort but is not owned by the resort? In any event, the Double Cut Pork Loin Chop was one of the best pork loin chops I've ever had (and we know pork in North Carolina!). Overall, we had a very nice stay at Turtle Bay and definitely would return. Is it worth $450+ night, as many report paying? Probably not--very few places are in my opinion. But we paid significantly less than that, and at the lower price point we enjoyed, the Turtle Bay experience definitely was worth it.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing”
Reviews.Author: DZA_A
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 4 nights in August in a Junior Suite. I will state firstly that we did not prebook this hotel as we had made reservations at the Hyatt in Waikiki, but ended up not staying there even one night as their rooms were not satisfactory (I can't do carpet in the bathroom, but that is another review). We were in a desperate situation as other hotels were all fully booked, so we ended up here. We thought it would be ok based on the website. We were disappointed. However, it was better than the Hyatt. And it was a more relaxing location than Waikiki. This place was not really our cup of tea. We usually stay in 4 or 5 star hotels around the world (we travel frequently) , but prefer exclusive, boutique style hotels. Our preference generally is not hotels with hundreds or thousands of rooms that 'cater to the masses'. Turtle Bay Resort caters to the masses. Pump them in, pump them out. And the price is not that expensive so the hotel guests tend to be of an average quality, those not really looking for exclusivity. I have rated it 3 stars and not 2 or 1 mainly because the golf course was magnificent. My husband and I and our young son played golf a couple of times and really enjoyed ourselves. Also, the restaurant at the golf course (Lei Lei's I think) was very good. The rooms: Our junior suite was very roomy with lots of seating and the bed was comfortable. The decor was dated, but it seemed to be maintained ok. The carpet looked clean and on the website photos, looks fantastic, but my husband once took his shoes off and walked barefoot on the carpet and his feet were black after 10 minutes. The bathroom and dressing area was also spacious. The housekeeping staff were really slack (even though I left a $5 tip every day). There is one issue though that was a problem for us, and had it not been for the fantastic golf course, I would give this review less than 3 stars. Breakfast was included in our stay and we quickly realized that if we wanted to have a table by the window we actually needed to make a reservation, which we did every morning. The lady that ran the restaurant was completely rude, every single day. She was an older lady, and completely incapable of her job. Whomever hired her for that position really has done a disservice to the hotel. She not once EVER smiled, she would not look at anyone, she addressed people rudely. People in line waiting for a table would try and ask her something or get her attention and she ignored them all, every day. We showered her with kindness daily and said good morning to her, addressing her personally by name (from her name tag) trying to make a friendly impression hoping it would be returned. NO WAY, it never happened. This older lady has passed her expiration date and needs to retire, or else work in some capacity that does not involve other humans. We are not typically bothered by this type of behavior - everyone has a bad day from time to time, but she was unbelievable. In saying all that, there was another lovely young lady that was very helpful. She remembered us every day and would personally come out of the restaurant to get us as we waited in line as she remembered daily that we had a reservation. There seemed to be a line of people (probably 10 plus people) waiting to get a table every day. The hotel was very busy when we were there. Our son really enjoyed the pool area as it had a section with a small waterslide. The pool area was what you would expect at a resort that 'caters to the masses'. Lots of people everywhere, noisy, not enough lounge chairs. I would not call it relaxing. There are turtles in the bay, that was great. The snorkeling was not very good in the area. My advice. In all fairness, if you don't mind a 'middle of the road' hotel that caters to the masses, you are not concerned with service and loads of people and this type of hotel suits you, it is not a bad hotel. Just keep in mind that it is in no way exclusive and there is no class here. Overall, I would say we had a pretty good time, but it simply was not our taste. Indeed, the island of Oahu is not our taste. I would not go back to this hotel, nor would I go back to Oahu except to catch a flight to another island. Oahu was all new and hopping back in the 70's, which becomes obvious when you visit. It passed it's expiration date long ago.

Reviews.Title: “Mixed bag at Turtle Bay”
Reviews.Author: tunasf
Reviews.Content: After reading all the reviews, I had some reservations (no pun...) about our stay. We just returned from 3 nights at the resort. Recognizing that it was New Year's weekend, I would say that the stay was okay....certainly there were not the glitches that others have reported. Our room (ocean front, king DELUXE) was clean, and spacious. However, at $450 per night, I didn't expect to see furniture that was so scratched and dented (this was not shabby chic) and carpets with stains. Bear in mind that ALL rooms have an ocean view, so don't think that you are some how luckier than others when you snag that ocean view room. We did have an ocean view once we looked beyond the roof of some large ball room/banquet room. The bathroom was clean but in serious need of some upgrading from the 70's or 80's. Like others, there was no comfy chair or loveseat to snuggle up in with a good book and at this time of the year, the weather in Hawaii is always a bit iffy. It was "cold", rainy and very windy on 2 out of our 3 days. I am not so bothered by the $20 resort fee because this is typical of many resorts though I do wish they would just include it in the cost of the room. When you check in, they give you a list of what your resort fee includes--it is helpful, I guess. One of my biggest complaints was trying to use the website to contact the concierge to make dinner reservations. The website's phone number for the concierge would just ring and ring and ring, so I attempted to use email to contact them. It became an annoying back and forth and it turned out that when we arrived, the reservations were not correct, but this did get resolved after beomg sent to three different people. I think that while the staff is very pleasant and tries to be helpful, there is a lack of training and follow up.Over all, it was great to escape from Waikiki, but since Turtle Bay is literally the only resort on the North Shore, it is the only game in town and has no competition. Ola's and 21 Degrees North were again just okay--we had just spent the previous four nights in Waikiki doing the fine dining scene so we had a standard that is tough to compare it to. I do find it sooo interesting that 21 Degrees North was not open on New Year's Eve--why? because they are ALWAYS closed on Mondays! Overall--beautiful natural setting--typical resort issues (high prices for food, not enough chairs at pool and beach) and a resort that doesn't have to work too hard because of a lack of competition nearby, friendly staff.

Reviews.Title: “possibilities”
Reviews.Author: jaki
Reviews.Content: As there is talk of this hotel being sued for foreclosure we had concerns about what we would find. The good - the location, snorkeling with a sea turtle, the view from our room and the mai tais The not so good - the food and the service and attitude of those who worked in the restaurants and bars- we even witnessed rivalry over who would serve a table. We also had booked one of the restaurants for the last night of our stay and when we arrived were informed that we would need to either purchase the buffet - very expensive - or wait an hour for our food as they were backed up in the kitchen (the restaurant was less than half full). As there was no other choice we ate the buffet. When checking out the next day we asked for a reduction in the food charge- their response was to take off $15. A response yes however less than adequate considering the total was $127 for 3 people. The rooms were ok- nothing fancy as mentioned before but clean. I would recommend this hotel as there is not much else in the area but I will definately be checking into other choices for our next trip. The North Shore- fabulous- we even saw a whale, when on a remote beach, that breached right in front of us and stayed in the area for 45 minutes. Extraordinary!

Reviews.Title: “Problems at Turtle Bay Resort”
Reviews.Author: MinnesotaNellie
Reviews.Content: Our stay at Turtle Bay was supposed to be the highlight and capstone of our two week trip to 3 different Hawaiian Islands. Unfortunately, it fell short of our expectations. First of all, let me say that we were there during some pretty bad storms so the power was out for almost 24 hours. This was outside of their control and we realize this. However, the experience during this time could have been exceedingly better and even after the power was restored, there were issues. The power went off sometime in the middle of the night. When I got up, I was confused about what was going on, but since I had booked a rather expensive private horseback ride, I got ready in the dark and headed downstairs to check in for that. When I got down there, I was told about the power outage and that there would be no riding as the concierge could not make it in. That was understandable. We heard that there would be a "limited" breakfast served in one of the restaurants. So, we went to that. The food was cold, many things were out, and there were no clean tables to sit at. Again, this is understandable given the situation BUT, the charge of $15.00 each for this was unacceptable. $5.00 would have been more appropriate for what we got. So, we ended up spending most of the day on the beach (don't need electricity for that!). I again, signed up for a private ride on the beach the next am, just in case power was restored. We were leaving the next day so it was my last chance to do this event that I had been so looking forward to. The power did finally come back on at about 9:00pm that evening so I was hopeful that I would be able to get that dream ride. So, I got up early again for the 2nd day in a row (not my style on vacation). Went ddownstairs and was AGAIN told that there would be no ride. WHY? Well, it was sprinkling a bit so not sure if no rides go out in the rain but was told that I should call later to see if they were taking the horses out. I tried to call MANY times. Never any answer. In my mind, there is no reason why they were not taking rides out and if they just wanted to wait until the shower passed (which it did about 30 minutes after) why didn't they call me to see if we could make it work out? They didn't. So, I was very dissappointed. So, we decided to go to the beach for a few hours before we needed to head back to the airport. This was about 9:30am. We went to the the hut to get towels and chairs (complimentary for guests) and found no one was there (this service is scheduled to start at 7:30). We waited for a bit and then had someone from the near by restaurant call up to see what the deal was. They were told, no towel/chair service due to "high seas". Well, there had been "high seas" since we got there with no impact on towel/chair service. And what does high seas have to do with laying on the beach? Nothing! We went up to our room and got our own towels so we could soak up a few last rays. Then, we went to our room and started packing to leave. As we looked down at the beach from our balcony, we saw that people were NOW getting chairs and towels. That was very frustrating. The power had been back on since the night before, the roads were clear and passable so there is no reason why FULL services should not have been in place that am. So, overall, the staff did a good job managing this power outage. My main complaint is about what happened afterwards. This is a beautiful resort and I was so dissappointed that I was not able to take advantage of all the amenities they advertise. On a positive note. I did talk to the front desk about my concerns and they did credit our room for the two $15.00 breakfasts and also removed the "resort fee" for both days. This was a nice gesture but I don't think it quite made up for the issues.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful stay at the Turtle Bay”
Reviews.Author: skamper4
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Turtle Bay resort for 11 nights in October 2007. We were married on the island of Oahu and spent our Honeymoon at the property. It was a wonderful experience. I had booked the room before reading the reviews, and after reading some of the negative ones I was a little nervous. That all subsided after we arrived at the resort. What a difference from Waikiki/Honolulu. The property is gorgeous. The staff were all friendly and helpful. Our room was clean and had a breathtaking view. The beaches, there are many to choose from, were beautiful. We seen many sea turtles and beautiful fish while snorkeling mere steps from the hotel. While walking the beach we happened upon a hawaiian monk seal sleeping on the beach. There is horseback riding and helicopter rides right on the property. There is miles of beaches and trails, and we found a couple of beaches with the only footprints being our own. We had a wonderful time and I would highly recommend this resort to anyone. I would never stay in Waikiki after having stayed at this resort. I cant wait to go back.

Reviews.Title: “Oceanfront cottages -- expensive, but worth it”
Reviews.Author: Bootsy31
Reviews.Content: We spent three nights at Turtle Bay to celebrate my birthday. I considered booking a room in the main hotel, but opted for one of the oceanfront cottages because I knew we just wanted to spend a few days relaxing in a surfside cocoon rather than have an active weekend of hiking, snorkeling, etc. I also was wary of the hotel rooms after reading numerous Trip Advisor reviews describing somewhat shabby conditions. We arrived late, around midnight, and the front desk clerk was friendly and helpful. I had requested a cottage with a king bed, but since only cottages with queen beds were available, she offered us a larger suite on the top floor of the hotel. I'm glad I stayed with the cottage, which was one of the nicest accommodations I have ever experienced. The cottages are like studio apartments, designed shotgun-style with a spacious bathroom near the door, a central sleeping area beneath 15-foot cathedral ceilings, a small sitting area with a desk facing the ocean and a loveseat, and then a veranda with a table, two chairs and a rocking chair. All that sits between you and the beach is a grassy walkway about 12 feet across. If you like the sights and sounds of surf mixed with the amazing tropical air of Hawaii, it's hard to imagine a nicer spot. There are 42 cottages, placed in 5-6 groups along the shorefront and apart from the hotel. We stayed in cottage 131, about as close to the ocean as you could get. There were other cottages set back farther from the beach for those who prefer more lawn between them and the ocean. The pictures and floor maps available on the hotel web site are accurate and I would suggest looking at them. [---] There's no question that the food and other services are very pricey at the hotel. In addition to the irritating $20 daily resort fee mentioned by other reviewers, all of the restaurants are expensive. We had room service breakfast one morning, which was an indulgence, but on the other days we just walked up to the hotel lobby and bought coffee from the coffee stand along with some fresh pineapple or other fruit. The coffee stand also had pastries, yogurt and protein bars. There is a sundry store in the resort where you can buy sandwich makings, soft drinks, milk, beer, wine, etc. and save some money. Even better, there's a Foodland supermarket maybe 10 minutes away where you can stock your fridge with food for breakfast and lunch and then splurge on dinner if you want. We had lunch at the poolside bar one day (a sandwich and fries will run you $15) and two meals at Ola restaurant with similarly high prices. We didn't eat at the breakfast buffet or try the special occasion restaurant on the property. The restaurant menus are on the hotel web site, so you can check out the prices and selections in advance. [---] I can't quibble with the food prices, which aren't that much higher than what you'd find at other full service resorts and which I expected after doing my research. I was, however, a little disappointed in some aspects of the service. There is a "concierge" assigned to the cottages, and he showed up the first day to promise he'd return each day with fresh fruit and water but we didn't really see him again after he dropped off those first two apples. When I ordered room service, I specifically requested a table setting for two, but only received one. In the bathroom, there were a few ants on the floor and a baby gecko that kept showing up near the sink (we thought he was cute, but others might not agree). These are small things, but when you pay these kind of prices for a room, there is an expectation that everything should be perfect. Due to booking during the off-season, we got a "deal" on the cottage booked through the hotel web site. Keep checking the Special Offers page and playing with the reservation engine to see what you can find. Despite my comments about the service, we had a glorious weekend there and I wouldn't hesitate to return.

Reviews.Title: “Avoid at all costs, Four Seasons Price... Holiday Inn Value”
Reviews.Author: LordHonna
Reviews.Content: Please be advised before reading that I specifically waited several weeks before posting my review in order to ensure that my description was "fair and balanced." As such, I have decided to give Turtle Bay Resort two stars (instead of one) for the reasons articulated below. Additionally, I fully disclose that I arrived at Turtle Bay with my wife on our Honeymoon after leaving the Four Seasons in Lana'i. Although I did not expect THAT level of service or attention to detail, the price did not match the value at all. Turtle Bay Resort is located on the North Shore of Oahu, about a forty-five minute drive from Honolulu without traffic. We reserved a three-night (convertible car included) stay for about $700 per night. We had rationalized the cost of our oceanfront cottage because it was the most expensive hotel booked on our three week journey. The North Shore is essentially a sleepy surfing destination and there isn't much to do in the area or at the resort. The views are truly spectacular, but that is the only thing going for Turtle Bay Resort. As stated in other reviews, the $20 daily fee is absurd. Why not just charge me $720 for the room in advance instead of angering me with a "parking" change when I have no other way to get to the resort besides driving Our room had been renovated within the last year or two but it was borderline filthy. The rugs and bedding were stained and our TV cabinet was broken with the door hanging off the hinge. As the icing on the cake, our screen door was ripped wide open and although maintenance "fixed" the issue, looking at duct tape in a $700 per night room was beyond annoying. The "business center" was dated and did not provide adequate internet access. I am quite sure they charge for access, but we couldn't even get the Commodore 64's to respond anyway. The included breakfast was pedestrian at best and it was during the meal (when I noticed stains and crumbs everywhere in the dining area) that I decided we would request cancellation of the rest of our stay. To Turtle Bay's credit, they did allow us to leave with no penalty or charges and were polite in accommodating us. To be fair, if we were paying $300 per night, Turtle Bay might have been manageable. That said, at this price point, the level of service and the lack of attention to detail was wholly unacceptable. Apologies for offending anyone who loves Turtle Bay, but there are any number of places to stay in Maui (or even Waikiki) that blow Turtle Bay away in terms of comfort, value and exclusivity. For $650 a night, Four Seasons Lodge at Koele or Manele Bay are beyond comparison. Good luck!

Reviews.Title: “Gorgeous Grounds vs. Substandard Room . . .”
Reviews.Author: bibliomom
Reviews.Content: We booked a deluxe ocean-view king for the fabulous "no-refund rate" of $240 a night -- a pretty good deal for a one night get away while visiting friends on Oahu. If only we had actually paid that -- after fees (like the ludicrous $20 'resort fee') and taxes, we paid a little over $300 -- it would have been . . . okay. The grounds are gorgeous -- really gorgeous -- and our deluxe ocean view really was a full on ocean view; if I had a better arm, I could have chucked something in from the balcony. At first glance the room looked okay, but on closer inspection, it was just a little too worn. The mattress and bedding was more appropriate for a roadside motel -- cheap and rough -- and while there was a lightweight feather comforter, they chose to layer it between two cheap flat sheets, thus ensuring that all three flat sheets (obviously their bedding of choice) would come loose at some point during the night. In other words, the bed was a total uncomfortable mess. Not so great for a one night get away. The bathroom continued the theme of inexplicable cheapness -- toiletries that *looked* nice, but were utterly cheap and nasty, and the towels that went with them. We did have a great time walking around the grounds the next morning -- it's not like we could sleep in, in that bed -- but I did appreciate the something like *9* signs on one of the beaches, warning you not to go in the water because of rocks, strong currents, strong wave break, jellyfish . . . the list goes on. Of course I realize it's winter and the waves are stronger, but I'd really hope there's a beach somewhere on the resort that could be used by mere mortals. Then we made the mistake of eating breakfast at the hotel -- yes, they had a woman making omelets, but other than that, the food was substantially worse than even a cheap restaurant -- overcooked omelets, soggy hashbrowns, limp waffles, and fruit flies buzzing around the mandatory cheap muffin counter. Again, a nice view, but poor quality food that had been left sitting far too long. Hard to swallow at $25 per buffet plate; if you must eat there, order ala carte. I should probably say a word about the staff here: they were fabulous. The waitresses at the restaurant were kind and attentive (they even had a carafe of real tea) -- they were the ones who recommended the omelet over the scrambled eggs who had been sitting there for "who-knows-how-long". The valets, desk staff and pretty much everyone else we asked for help were just excellent -- they're one of the two stars I gave this review, the other being the grounds and view. The exception was the security hut, which required us to show them our room card every time we entered or left the grounds. This *might* make sense, if it wasn't for the valet pass in our windshield and the fact that the grounds are public access -- why are we being hassled *more* then if we had just come to use the beach? But this goes along with their general attitude of treating their guests like ex-cons -- you're given one towel car per person upon check in and you must trade it back and forth for clean and dirty towels. If you lose the card (or the towel) you'll be charged $25 per card upon checkout. Cups and the cutesy stuffed animal they leave in the room are similarly labeled with exorbitant fees that will be charged if these items go missing. I'm used to the little sign saying, "if you'd like to purchase this, please take it home and we'll charge xx $" -- I'm not used to them in such bountiful qualities. I've stayed at a variety of hotels that range from Motel 6 to uber-pricey -- Turtle Bay pretends to be the later but has all the amenities of the former. Basically: nice grounds & good staff vs. a resort run by penny pinching accountants who cut corners on everything that isn't the grounds or the lobby, and who charge countless fees designed to nickel and dime you into oblivion. Fussy and cheap all at the same time just isn't my idea of a fun place to stay. We won't be going back.

Reviews.Title: “My favorite hotel in Oahu”
Reviews.Author: schererd
Reviews.Content: I LOVE this hotel! It's slogan is "True Hawaii", and I agree, get out of Waikiki and stay here in the North Shore! Waikiki is just a normal city, you might as well go to Chicago or Los Angeles or Boston. Hawaii is supposed to be tropical rainforests and waterfalls and unspoiled beaches, and Turtle Bay delivers 1,000 percent. It's very luxurious (there are two other hotels that are more luxurious in my opinon if you're looking for top of the like, Halekulani in Waikiki and The Kahala on the opposite side of Diamond Head, but I'd take the Turtle Bay and it's seclusion over either of those two hotels) and offers everything you'd expect at a top of the line resort, multiple gourmet restaurants (very expensive also), a wonderful spa, a great pool with an ocean view from the pool, wonderful staff, etc. etc. The rooms are a tad on the small side but very well appointed. The grounds are meticulously kept and the beach is great. I was a little bit concerned about the waves being too big since this is supposed to be the top surfing spot in North America but I had no problem at all. Even though I'm pretty sure it's an older property it looked pristine and brand new, like it had just opened the week before. It has wonderful floor-to-ceiling glass windows in the lobby that face out over the ocean and I'm told at the right time of year you can whale-watch from the lobby! Absolutely the only hotel to stay at in Oahu!

Reviews.Title: “Needs renovation - ridiculous resort fee”
Reviews.Author: pedro2007Sba
Reviews.Content: We have bought a 4-day package (hotel & flight from LAX) at yahoo.travel. At check-in, they told us we should pay another 20 USD a day for services for e.g. self-parking - in a resort with nothing around. The rooms were nice and clean with a beautiful view to the ocean. But don't look behind anything - the room incl. bathroom was waiting for a renovation. I guess the hotel started as a 4-star hotel - but there are hardly 3 stars left - besides the prices.

Reviews.Title: “My favorite place in the world! Go in the winter for the beautiful waves!!”
Reviews.Author: MnJ_102007
Reviews.Content: We have stayed at Turtle bay twice....February 2007 and February 2005. February is a wonderful time to be on the North Shore because the waves are amazing. The view of the ocean at Turtle Bay in February is what I had always pictured when I thought of Hawaii. The rooms are very nicely furnished and comfortable. Every room is ocean view due to the hotel's design, which is a great feature. Wireless internet access is a great feature of the hotel, especially since I can't adjust to the time change from the east coast, so it gave me something to do at 3am when I woke up!!!! We always eat dinner one at 21 degrees north, and had a great meal each time. We love the hotel's location on the north shore. There are two good Mexican restaurants in nearby Haleiwa, Cholo's and Rosie's Cantina. I love Oahu, because you get that true Hawaiian feeling on the North Shore, but you can also take an hour drive to Honolulu for the comforts of home...malls, familiar restaurants, etc. I recommend combining a trip to Turtle Bay on Oahu with another island destination We got engaged on our second trip here, so this will always be a special place to me.

Reviews.Title: “Love this place paradise”
Reviews.Author: tlc391964
Reviews.Content: I am actually at Turtle Bay while I write this. It has been a remarkable stay. Everything and the hotel staff has far exceeded my expectation. Beautiful,Beautiful hotel. Well kept. I can see turtles swimming in the ocean right outside my balcony view. Would recommend hotel highly.

Reviews.Title: “I didn't want to leave paradise!”
Reviews.Author: Mindi_in_CO
Reviews.Content: My boy friend and I stayed at the Turtle Bay Resort from 10/20/07-10/27/07. The location on the North Shore of Oahu was exactly what I was hoping for - a relaxing retreat. If you want wild night life and crowds, stay in Waikiki. Our room was on the 6th floor. A few days prior to us arriving I called and requested a room on the 6th floor because I read on TripAdvisor that the higher the floor the better the view. (The 6th floor is the top floor) When we arrived at check in they had my request and had honored it. We were in room 673 which overlooked the pool and the ocean. The room was clean and comfortable with a large lanai (balcony). The bed has all white bedding and was very comfortable. The pillows were a foam type, which I prefer. If you like down or softer pillows, you would need to ask for them. The bathroom was big. It had a separate shower and toilet/sink and then another vanity/sink area with a small refrigerator. They also had a decent hair dryer and a make-up mirror. They provided soap, shampoo, conditioner, and body lotion. The bath products are made by Gilchrist & Soames and are decent in quality. There was also a table with a coffee maker and everything you need to make coffee. There was plenty of closet and drawer space and a small safe for valuables. The hotel does charge a daily $20 resort fee on top of whatever your reservation price that you paid. This fee will get charged to your credit card that you put down for incidental charges. They do give you wireless internet access and you can use snorkel gear for an hour each day and some other benefits that are clearly explained to you at check-in. $20 a day did seem steep. The hotel staff were all very nice and very accommodating. The room was cleaned twice per day and I thought they did a great job. I especially liked the chocolate turtles they left on our pillow at night. I also liked the restaurants at the hotel. Yes, a bit pricey too, but it is Hawaii and things are more expensive and it is a resort and at this point if you are reading this, you have been warned. We had the Prime Rib Buffet and the breakfast buffet several times. We also had the Sunday brunch which was very good. We had dinner at Ola's which is right on the sand - this should not be missed! I did have one burger by the pool - the burger was good and it came with fries, but it cost $15 (plus tax and tip on top) - which I did find a bit over the top. We did go to Foodland (the market) early on in the trip and stock our refrigerator with water and snacks and beer. They have small bottles of Fiji water in the room for $3.50/bottle. We went to the market and bought a six pack of Dasani for $3.00. It just made more sense for us. The pool area and the beach were both kept clean. I did spend more time at the pool. The one day my boy friend went solo snorkeling he did see a big turtle - a definite highlight of his trip. While in the North Shore definitely spend time in Haleiwa the famous small surf town. We had lunch at Kono's in the North Shore Marketplace. The food was excellent and it is definitely a place where the locals "hang out." We also had a couple of good breakfasts at Ted's Bakery in Sunset Beach - just a few minutes from the hotel. This is a wonderful bakery, but they also serve omelets and breakfast sandwiches. This is clearly a favorite of the local surfers too. We did try the famous shrimp trucks too. I had the garlic shrimp - they were peel and eat and my hands smelled like garlic for several days. They were delicious. One more thing - a car rental is a must have if you are going to stay here. Getting around the island is relatively simple. We indulged ourselves and got a convertible - the weather is so nice and driving with the top down is simply great!

Reviews.Title: “Luxury Resort a true Hawaiian experience”
Reviews.Author: LouReid
Reviews.Content: I stayed here with my husband at the end of our honeymoon for 4 nights. We stayed in an ocean view room which had a stunning view over turtle bay, very modern decor and a very comfortable bed! The resort itself is huge, it has a famous golf course where they play the USA international golf tournaments, a huge swimming pool, walking tracks, beach, waterslide and more. There is fairly good snorkling at the resort too just off the beach, you can hire snorkling gear and snorkle to your hearts content - didn't see any turtles while we were there though! The snorkling wasn't as good as in Hanama Bay Honolulu, that is a must for snorklers! The position of the resort makes it a very windy spot, windy to the point of towels and sunglasses blowing away by the pool etc. But maybe that also has something to do with the time of year, we were there in April. Very relaxing spot though but you must have car hire up there as there is nothing else around the resort and you need to car to get out and see the north shore. I don't know if I'd stay here again, I loved the atmosphere in Honolulu more but for those who want to get away from the city to a more relaxing spot to experience Hawaii and it's beautiful beaches, Turtle Bay Resort may be for you!

Reviews.Title: “Loved Turtle Bay”
Reviews.Author: Shanalane
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Turtle Bay for 4 days and loved it! One side faces the sunrise and the other side faces the sunset. We watched the beautiful sun rise every morning. Next time we will request the sunset side. You can't wrong either way. Rent a car and go to the North Shore. It's a great surfing town and has wonderful little shops.

Reviews.Title: “Incredible setting but...”
Reviews.Author: BinAround
Reviews.Content: Just returned from 4 nights at the Turtle Bay resort in Oahu. It is a lovely property on a point overlooking amazing views of the rugged yet gorgeous coastline of the North Shore. Great beach options, nice pool area and the rooms are fine and very comfortable- ask for a high floor facing the ocean. The service is very nice. However, the food options are limited, bad and expensive. Pick up water and snacks on your way there, and go back down the road to Romy’s shrimp shack for dinner before 6pm! The other drawback is that, being on the point surrounded by the ocean it is very, very windy- In the Fall anyway. Obviously this is no fault of the hotel, but something to consider if you enjoy relaxing by the pool doing anything other than holding down all of your possessions. Nonetheless, it is beautiful spot and the area is culturally interesting. We suggest 2-3 nights there and then on to Maui!

Reviews.Title: “Lovely place, would recommend”
Reviews.Author: metalliam
Reviews.Content: Stayed here for 4 nights, Sept 14th - 18th 2007. We booked an Ocean View room and ended up technically being able to see the sea, but mostly a roof...they did offer to move us as soon as possible, but I didn't bother in the end because it's not that big of a deal - it's always warm enough (and more enjoyable) to be outside, either by the poolside area, or on the beach. They light up the waves at night, and combined with the fire thingies they have and a cocktail, it's very nice. Very nice indeed. The room itself was great, very clean, it has a decent fridge and coffee/tea making facilities, great shower etc. We paid about $1000 total for the 4 nights we were there, and I'd say we got good value. I wasn't pleased to see they'd tacked on $20 (which turned out to only be $15) a day onto our stay for certain "amenities" guests wanted to be included in the bill, such as parking, snorkel hire, internet access, use of gym and a few more....to me this seemed ultra cheeky, and upon checking the prices of the food, I was suddenly glad we'd saved money whilst in Waikiki by staying at a cheaper (but fine, nonetheless) hotel. It seemed we were going to need it....however... ...Coming from England and benefitting from a great exchange rate, I'd have to say the food prices wern't really that bad, or that different from anything else we've experienced on several trips to various places around the States. Expect things to be a little more expensive due to the location of the place, but it's not too bad. We didn't get to eat in the 21 degrees restaurant, but ate everywhere else. The place that serves the buffet (can't remember the name) was pretty decent, had a friendly waiter, and the food was really good (I had a full rack of ribs and a seafood chowder). For a starter, entree, and some beer, including a decent tip and tax, for me it was $50. Not bad at all, really. We ate at Ola's also, a very nice chicken dish. Great setting, down by the beach, i'd advise you to reserve. Again, not too expensive considering the setting. Another night we were looking for a quick bite late on, and the Bay Club had some chicken strips and fries for about $9, filled us right up...fairly priced. As for the area itself, it was absolutely stunning. If you want to see a decent sunset away from everyone else, head towards the WW2 bunker, gives you a nice place to sit. There are a few trails for walking around the area, which is nice. The snorkeling - an hour of which a day is "included" in the $20 daily charge, is excellent. You really do get to see a decent amount of underwater critters, and an hour is more than enough. The pool and 2 hottubs are both cool, and the beaches around the area are great - nothing like Waikiki, you could probably walk 10 minutes and be the only people on the beach. There is a small shop on site, which sells beer, cereal, chips, pot noodle etc....you're not supposed to consume cans purchased in here down by the pool, but who cares when you've so much beach to use? Whilst up on the North Shore, we went down to Haleiwa for the Shark Encounter, which was really cool, and we also went to the Polynesian Cultural Centre. You can get The Bus to both places pretty easily. The PCC is well worth a visit. I would say, however, that if you've been to the Beachfront in Waikiki in the evening, you don't need to stick around at the PCC for the Luau. The interactive activities available in the daytime are much more fun than the evening show, too. The Luau was fine, but it wasn't exactly sitting around a campfire talking to locals, it's basically just a buffet with performers down front dancing. Overall, the Turtle Bay is a great place to stay, and well worthwhile if you want to experience serenity after the hustle and bustle of Waikiki. In fact, I can't imagine i'd of been very impressed with Oahu had I just stayed in Waikiki and not been up to the North Shore. A notice to travellers not planning on renting a car: THE BUS DOES NOT ALLOW LARGE LUGGAGE! The hotel we stayed at in Waikiki let us store our luggage for a pittance compared to the $150 each way fare that a taxi would have cost from Waikiki. We simply packed up a smaller bag with everything we'd need, locked our luggage and had it stowed in Waikiki, and went about our business. We booked a shuttle back to the airport from the Waikiki hotel. It takes about 3 hours in total to get from Waikiki to the Turtle Bay using the bus, it's a long time but it's totally worth it for the money you save.

Reviews.Title: “The best vacation of my life!!”
Reviews.Author: TofanelliL
Reviews.Content: We just completed a 6 day stay at Turtle Bay...and I am so depressed to be home! I am an avid tripadvisor user so this review may be a little long Room: We stayed in the beach cottages - - if you can swing in you MUST stay there. We stayed in cottage 114 which looked directly at the beach/ocean had a wonderful bed. I can't imangine staying at the actual hotel...we used one of the rooms on our last day as a hospitality suite (make sure you are at least on the third floor because the view is terriable from the second) Food: I was not impressed with 21 degress the servie was horriable, my food subpar. (one caveat...we ate there on our first night on the island so we were really tired) Olas was great. The food amazing, right at the beach, which was great for sunset LeiLeis: perfect for breakfast - cheep and open early so if you want to get a jump on the day. other food in the area that is not to miss Ted's Bakery - about 10 minutes from Turtle Bay - they have amazing pie, breakfast foods Kona's Surfer Cafe - in Haleiwei - 20 minutes from Turtle Bay - great breakfast and smoothies. Activies: We played Golf...great course, challenging - we rented our clubs for $30 and played a round after 2:00PM which we got walk-up afternoon rates and played the round for around $120 Pools are nice, clean and warm. The have a great slide that we had fun at...good change. It is windy so be ready for showers most days. The beach calm...good for snorkeling. The best place we found to snorkle is called sharks cove about 15 minutes from TB right accross from the foodland Overall this area of Oahu was beautiful....I would go back in a heartbeat

Reviews.Title: “Great stay at Turtle Bay”
Reviews.Author: notrub98
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Turtle Bay for two nights in July for the start of our honeymoon. Overall, the hotel is beautiful, great beach, good restaurants, excellent room quality! The bathroom was immaculate and well-maintained, the bed very comfy, and we were greeted with a complimentary bottle of champagne from the hotel's manager. The only negative would be the location as it is the opposite direction of Pearl Harbor. This is fine if you are not going to the attraction but it was inconvenient for us since we only had a couple of days on Oahu. All in all, it was a great stay and we would highly recommend it!

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful views, bugs in bread”
Reviews.Author: waileabride
Reviews.Content: We just got back from a Hawaiian vacation that included one night at Turtle Bay. We moved there from Waikiki after getting a really bad room at the Sheraton. I'd never stayed on the North Shore and we thought it was really beautiful. Our room was very nice, comfortable, with an ocean view partially obstructed by palm trees, but we didn't care since it was better than our Sheraton room. The staff was not as friendly as the Sheraton, but they were alright. We loved the pool and the sunset view. It was a great place to swim, dry off, and watch the sunset. We didn't see that many kids and although the place was supposedly sold out, it didn't seem that crowded. The only thing bad I have to say is that the food was gross. It's one thing to be overpriced and good, but another to pay $60 for a lunch buffet where you can't eat the bread because there are bugs all over it. There were bugs all over much of the fruit, and all of the bread. The silverware was dirty in every restaurant we ate in. Food options are limited. If you can get around the food issue, Turtle Bay is a beautiful, relaxing, and peaceful spot to rest and enjoy great sunsets.

Reviews.Title: “old and average”
Reviews.Author: k1tty
Reviews.Content: The Turtle Bay Resort has a beautiful location on a promontory on the north shore of Oahu, and as such beautiful ocean views abound from many of the rooms and on the grounds. However, the resort is definitely not of a top caliber when it comes to service and food. The room next door to us, with whom we shared an adjoining door, suffered a malfunctioning door so that the poor guests staying there were locked out of their room. After spending all morning listening to the guests and hotel staff trying to get the door to open, they ended up accessing their room through the adjoining door in our room. They then proceeded to begin repairs to their door, calling it an "emergency." The maintenance staff kept our door propped open, along with the adjoining door, so they could run power cords through them, and people kept walking in and out for about an hour, not to mention the ridiculous amount of noise all of these proceedings and repairs made. I cannot fathom why the hotel's first thought would not be to immediately move us and the guests from next door to new rooms before beginning all of this ruckus. We had to call guest services repeatedly to ask about finding us a new room. When they did find one, it took another set of phone calls (and about half an hour) to get a bellhop to come to our room to help us move all of our luggage, and more importantly, give us new keys! The next room was directly above the pool which perhaps some people would be ok with, but as we had liked to keep our balcony doors open to hear the waves crashing, it was a letdown to instead listen to alot of screaming children (I don't mind kids at all, and had alot of fun at the pool watching them play, but when I'm trying to take a nap it's a different story). They finally found us a new room, and did offer to deduct $50 from our final bill, but that's no excuse for completely mishandling the situation. I think when running such a large complex, malfunctions and accidents are bound to happen, and it's about how the management responds to such occurrences, which in this case was disappointing. On to the food, I would recommend staying away from the Palm Terrace and the Bay Club, which both served food ranging from mediocre to awful. Ola had nice food, but more importantly, a wonderful location right on the beach. 21 degrees was nice and everyone (about 6 of us) enjoyed their meal, but of course for the prices they charge ($50 for a ribeye entree!) I would expect no less. I did very much enjoy sitting on their beach, whose sand is a bit on the rocky side as beaches go. But Hawaii is brimming with beaches, so I am not sure it's reason enough to stay at Turtle Bay.

Reviews.Title: “Disappointing”
Reviews.Author: yasiColorado
Reviews.Content: The hotel was a disappointment. We found hair in the hotel room service food twice. We waited at the pool for our drinks for 45 minutes one day, and never received our order of buffalo wings. The pool wait staff spent more time talking to each other than tending to the guests. They were not friendly and definitely did not live up their reputation for hospitality. We not only had to track them down to place orders we also had to track them down to close our check out each day. I have traveled to Europe many times, been on many cruises, I travel to resorts in Mexico every Christmas and I have been to Hawaii once prior to this trip. This was by far the worst vacation I have ever been on. In all honesty this is the only bad vacation experience I have ever had. The lack of customer service ruined the trip. I would strongly advise you not to choose this hotel. The only good thing about the hotel is the beautiful property is it located on. Hiking was the highlight of our trip.

Reviews.Title: “TBR--was aweful, extremely disappointed!!”
Reviews.Author: Bailey07
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at TBR in July to celebrate my 40th and our 6th year wedding anniversary. We came from Waikiki beach, which we loved by the way, and were looking forward to a wonderful, relaxing 3 night stay at TBR. We were greatly disappointed!!! We checked in, the lobby was OK, with a beautiful view of the water from floor to ceiling glass windows. Went up to our room, and here's where it gets bad.......... we reserved a Pikaki suite and got a room on the 5th floor, over looking the ocean. Walked into our room, and it was extremely hot and smelled musty and dusty. Walked over to the window to step out on the balcony, which could barely fit 2 small chairs on it. Went into the bathroom to freshen up, and it smelled like urine! Also, one of the towel racks was broken, but I could handle a broken towel rack, just not the urine smell! Talked to front desk, and told them we needed to change rooms and mentioned why. Even offered to down grade into a regular room if neccesary. Said they were completely booked up, but had one room left, and it was a handi-capped room, with 2 double beds instead of a king, like we had wanted. Also it was on the 2nd floor over-looking the roof and part of the pool. Definately NOT an ocean view! We took it anyways, as I didn't want to smell dust and urine for the next 3 nights. Turned the AC on high in our 2nd floor room, since the room was very hot, and went to the pool. Had drinks at the pool. Which were fine. Pricey as any other resort would be of this nature. Went to Ola's for a dinner. The food was very good! The service, not. The server never offered bread or a desert menu. The only reason we knew about the possibity of bread, is that all the other diners had some! Also, when we complimented the chef on his food, she happen to mention that the chef wasn't there and "is never around much these days, as he just had a new baby". Thought that was rather rude to mention. Got back up to the room, and it was only 2 degrees cooler than in the afternoon! AC did not work, and was very loud. Bed was very uncomfortable. Found ants in bathroom! Furniture was very old and worn. Stains on carpeting. Need I mention more?? The next morning, got up and checked out IMMEDIATELY! The front desk girl was very nice about it, asked very few question, and even offered to help us locate another hotel to stay in. It almost seemed as though this had happened to her before. Checked out and went to the JW Marriott in KO Olina, which was fabulous! (different review!) I would never return to TBR, and would never reccommend this resort to anyone else. It is in need of some serious renovating. And from what I was hearing on the island, it is up for sale.

Reviews.Title: “Great location”
Reviews.Author: b11811
Reviews.Content: Great location on north shore. 10 minute drive to Waimea falls, Waimea Bay and the rest. Walking the grounds where they filmed Lost was very relaxing, I saw 3 turtles on the way. The beach is great for surfing, or the cove on the right side is less choppy for swimming. There is no lifeguard so probably best to stay at the pool or the safer beach unless surfing or experienced. My room was cleaned at least 2 or 3 times a day, and I had a king sized bed in an ocean view room and everything was great. It seemed like a great place for families and couples. Not a lot of single people, but the beach bar has fantastic views. A nice contrast to my previous stay in Waikiki and a good way to wind down. I will return.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful Vacation!”
Reviews.Author: debbiec66
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Turtle Bay from July 30 - August 6. It was truly amazing!! We got a free upgrade to an oceanfront room and the view was spectacular! We were in room 609 on the south wing. The other side had a partial view of the roof so make sure you ask for the south wing. The room was very clean and large. We had turn down service too, which was an nice touch. When we arrived, they had a bottle of chilled champagne ready for us. I think this is because they knew we were celebrating our 15th wedding anniversary. It was a nice gesture! We ate the breakfast buffet every morning which was really great...made-to-order omelets, scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage, ham, veggie quiche, hashbrowns, boiled eggs, belguim waffles or pancakes, fruit (wonderful pineapple!), miso soup, smoked salmon, various pastries, toast, bagels, etc. We ate at Lei Lei's and both had fabulous steaks. Make sure you go there. We also went to Ola's for lunch and had hamburgers and the pork quesadillas which were both really good. We had the fish tacos and hamburgers at the pool side grill which were great too. Try the Lava drink and the Pina Calada.......expensive ($9) but well worth it...they were fabulous!!
