Reviews.Content: We decided to splurge and stay at the Beach Cottages and it was well worth the cost. These Cottages sit right along the water on a lawn dotted with comfortable teak lounges and hammocks. The cottages are separate but adajacent to the main part of the hotel. Our cottage was very large with wood floors, a gorgeous bathroom, a wetbar with a fridge and beautiful porch with a table, two chairs and a rocking chair. The service was exquisite. We were taken care of by hotel staff, who checked with us each day and provided complimentary fruit in the morning, champagne, and a full tea at the hotel. We were only here for a few days so it was a lovely break from the other side of the island. It appears that the management is gradually upgrading and improving the entire hotel. The pool and beach were lovely. The only downside was the very high cost of the hotel food. They still need to add a gourmet market on the hotel grounds so that guests can purchase simple salads, soups, pastries and sandwiches. As an alternative, purchased food at the Foodland and ate on our porch or ate at restaurants in nearby towns. This hotel provides a really lovely setting with excellent service. We recommend it highly.

Reviews.Title: “Positive - but please read the review....”
Reviews.Author: a4qual
Reviews.Content: I’m very particular about hotels and travel regularly for business and pleasure. We wanted a low-key post-wedding break and this hotel/resort did the job. This hotel I would recommend to would be consumers with the following points: -Read the other recent reviews of this hotel on Tripadvisor – they really helped -Don’t book direct, go through an internet based service -You need a car if you want variety of cuisine / scenery – there are nearby towns (Haleiwa is by far the best for food, shopping etc) -The food at the hotel is ridiculously overpriced (around $45 for 2 burgers and drinks, over $30 for a steak etc). However the food is very good. Our advice: go to the nearby (5 or so miles West) store Foodland, ask for a free Foodland discount card and stock up your hotel fridge with nice stuff (champagne, deli, breakfast etc) – save lots of $. -Other prices are what you would expect – double the price of goods and services compared to prices in Haleiwa -The hotel will charge you an extra $15 per day which you have to pay (this covers coffee in house, parking space, access to the gym, daily hour snorkel rental etc and is based on their customer feedback (according to them). This is very annoying when you check in – we booked through Orbitz and this extra charge wasn’t made clear to us before arrival – not a good feeling when you check in – however the free wireless internet (which the inexplicably do not market for some reason) helps to make up for this charge Plus points: -The room and views are great – I stressed that I needed a top (6th) floor room as the views would be great – we were not disappointed -The room is clean (my wife is pregnant so very important) and the staff are reasonably helpful (although some of the wait-staff are spaced-out) -Good pool / decent beaches -The location is superb – surf / beach lovers are close to Haleiwa, the Pipeline and Sunset beach. Waikiki is only an hour away for those that want the city scene for a while -Access to yoga classes several times per week (around $7 per class) The ideal people staying here would be late 20s+ couples who want a good base to explore the north shore and chill out for a few days. If you don’t have a car, we feel this resort would get a little repetitive and very expensive after a few days of paying their prices. Other notes for beginner surfers: -Beware of the ‘surf club’ – this isn’t affiliated to the hotel and does capitalize on beginner surfers – hourly rental for boards for beginners is $15 –compared to $7 elsewhere and $10 for more advanced boards. I asked the unhelpful sultry chick behind the desk of the store why this was and she shrugged and said ‘more business – experienced surfers have their own boards’ – not a great attitude…. Needless to say they didn’t get my business -Beware of the surf lessons given by the Surf and Sea in Haleiwa – the $75/2 hour lesson I received was given by a guy who made us feel that he was doing us a favor by fraternizing with uncool novice surfers for the afternoon – maybe we just got unlucky with the instructor as otherwise that store was really cool and the staff were nice. My advice - ask to talk with the guy/gal who will give the lesson before paying for it. Parting note: We would recommend this to others with the above points in mind. I don’t mind paying $$$$ for something that I feel is worth the money – this hotel does provide value for money in terms of the view and access to facilities.

Reviews.Title: “Solid A- w/ Room for Improvement”
Reviews.Author: TennisTraveller
Reviews.Content: The best asset of the resort is the people - the staff at the Turtle Bay have to be some of the best in the entire hospitality industry. They are very caring, genuine and all have great knowledge about their own departments as well as other facilities of the resort. You will feel at home and feel like you are embraced by luxury at the same time. Golf and tennis are both must checks, needless to say. But for Pete's sake, update the bathroom - they look worn and tired! The bedroom area obviously look renovated, but the TVs are getting too old - unacceptable. I have written the resort management, I am not entirely against the idea of staying somewhere close and go up to the resort for a couple days for all the services. They do charge quite a bit, it is NOT too much to ask for an updated TV and more than a below average bathroom and vanity area.

Reviews.Title: “Best Resort Ever!!!”
Reviews.Author: Iduna10
Reviews.Content: For our fourth anniversary my husband and I took my parents to Hawaii for a much deserved family vacation. My aunt lives in Mililani Town but other than that I knew nothing about Hawaii or where to start booking our trip. I jumped on Expedia and searched through TONS of hotels and resorts. I knew my dad wanted to be on the North Shore and as soon as I saw Turtle Bay I knew I found our resort. The Resort is beautiful and as soon as you pull up to the indoor / outdoor lobby you are impressed. It is very secluded and quiet. The drive to the airport is great! The view from our room was awesome. Out our window we faced northeast at the ocean and could see all the way down the beach. The lush gardens and beautiful beach made this trip extra special. Our room was fantastic and very clean. My mother and I are neat freaks and it is very hard to get her to go on vacations but she had no complaints about the room or the hotel (5 stars). It was very easy to get anywhere in the hotel and all windows had supreme views. We were all very impressed. Plus the shops in the hotel had everything you need or just want. We ordered room service a couple of times and they were very friendly. Every one at Turtle Bay was so nice. One lady that worked at the hotel sat and talked with my mother about her garden and brought beautiful flowers to show every one at the resort. She was so proud of it. Now to the food…. WOW!!! We had coupons for the breakfast buffet every morning and it was soooo good. Only draw back is that we were to full most days to enjoy any other food! It was different every morning and to good to be true every morning. We had dinner at the same restaurant one night and again it was great. I was a little disappointed on our anniversary night. I wanted to eat at the other restaurant they have there but it was closed. I think it was Tuesday. We also missed the Friday Luau because we had tickets for the Polynesian Cultural Center. Try to plan the Cultural Center for a day during the week! All in all I can’t wait to get back there.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome stay at Turtle Bay!”
Reviews.Author: Chas12345
Reviews.Content: This resort surpassed our expectations. Though a bit expensive, the service and staff made our stay perfect. I can honestly say that Turtle Bay created an environment that allowed us to truly unplug and relax, while entertaining our 6 year old twins as well. A truly perfect vacation in a perfect resort.

Reviews.Title: “Awesome and Natural”
Reviews.Author: Irishlass42
Reviews.Content: Turtle Bay was everything I imagined it to be. The location was idylic and natural; away from the hustle bustle of Honolulu. The staff was friendly, waitstaff at Ola's on the beach was superb! The ocean-side spa service was incredible with natural oils and a view to die for. The grounds themself were incredible and lush. Definitely try the horseback riding and a hike to some of the quiet coves and beaches. The North Shore is amazing, for someone that has not seen Hawaii it was the way to go. The respect for the environment and the incredible food was great. We drove around a lot and explored the little towns along the North shore and East side of the Island. Haleiawa Beach was great for swimming and jumping in the waves. Shark's Cove for watching surfers and the Waimea Rainforest walk was incredible. Go to the Valley of the Temples, a must see and to also the China Man's hat and the little village of Lania. Definetly, worth the 9 1/2 hours to get there!

Reviews.Title: “A great place, but they need a little competition”
Reviews.Author: PolkHi
Reviews.Content: The North Shore is 'the country' and a great contrast to Waikiki, but there are few options for accomodation. We had never been to Hawaii before our stay this January and are glad we visited this part of Oahu. I had gathered from reading many earlier posts on this site that the resort has been going through a transformation of sorts. We would suggest the facilities were great, most of the restaurants were top notch [avoid the buffets at the Palm Terrace] and the location is ideal. The only drawback, as I had also read earlier, is that you have to get a deep discount to really see any value. I would not go back to this resort unless I had booked a last minute room. After our arrival I learned that our room would have been considerably cheaper had I check in on the internet and checked out at the front desk. That is what they suggested I do when I asked the front desk, as the rate posted on the internet for the room I was in was not available to them. Had I not been concerned with paying twice for an already overpriced room, I would have. If there was an alternative resort, I'd have gone there too just based on the attitude I received. Great spot, but overpriced. Next time, I'll drive up for the day.

Reviews.Title: “Turtle Bay Resort was worth every penny”
Reviews.Author: JBPortland
Reviews.Content: This was our first stay here. We came from nine days on Maui for the surfing, view, hiking trails, food and proximity to Haleiwa, and all of our goals were achieved. We had never surfed the North Shore, and the surf school provided us with two well-qualified instructors for 4 days of surfing. We caught waves we'd only dreamed about. The trails along the beach, golf course and in the woods were easy hikes and very pleasant. A bonus on one morning hike was a pod of breaching whales just outside Turtle Bay. We sampled all of the restaurants on the property, and we were pleased with all of them, especially Leilei's. The staff were very good about splitting the breakfast entrees for us because we were watching our weights this trip. They didn't charge us extra for that service. A special treat for my mixologist wife was a conversation about cocktails with the very knowledgeable bartender at Point 21 whose nickname, we learned, was "Stephatini." Twenty minutes down the road, past the Banzai Pipeline, Sunset Beach and Waimea was the North Shore Surfing Capitol, Haleiwa, with the Grass Skirt Grill, Banzai Sushi, Joe's, Jamieson's and the surf museum. We sampled the above-mentioned restaurants and visted the museum when Hurricane Bob, an award-winning senior surfer, was minding the store.

Reviews.Title: “Repeat Visitor”
Reviews.Author: ilovehawaiiBend
Reviews.Content: My husband and I have stayed at Turtle Bay Resort three different times. On our honeymoon 8 years ago, in 2003 and 2005. Each time we loved it.! We have watched TBR go from a 2-3 star to a 4-5 star property. Unfortunately, the price increased as well but it is well worth it. To experience "real" hawaii Turtle Bay is the perfect place. In fact as soon as my husband returns from Iraq in April we are heading out there again! A car is a must to visit TBR as it's approx 1 hour drive through pinapple fields and small coffee fields from Honolulu airport. The drive is peaceful and beautiful. TBR is on the famed North Shore by the Bansi Pipeline and Sunset beach. While there in Nov 2005 we were able to watch part of the Royal Crown surfing championships. The waves were so large that they occaionally spilled on to the roads. It's spetacular! They actually had to postpone the surfing for a day or two because the waves were so high. So if swimming is high on your list know that the North shore sports 30 to 50 ft waves during the winter months. There are plenty of other swimming sites closer to Honolulu. There is a nice cove for snorkling with outdoor showers to rinse off at the hotel itself that is protected enough to swim in during the winter. However, there are nicer snorkling beaches on Oahu. For example Hanamuma bay (spelling ?) is perfect year round. You won't find a better view of the ocean from any other hotel. TBR sits on a point in Turtle Bay, hence the name and boast miles of shoreline to meander through. Bring water shoes as sometimes the shore is rocky with coral and can cut barefeet. Yes, there are large sea turtle there and also laws to protect them so stay at least 5 -7 feet away from them and never try to touch them. There are several private coves around the resort so if your lucky you might find your self swimming with them. Don't be alarmed they mostly ignore humans. True, Turtle Bay is not in the same class as say The Orchid on Kona however it far surpasses a stateside Marriott or Hilton and never feels stuffy. The lobby was redone with an entire wall of windows facing directly out onto the ocean. On our last visit we stayed in one of the remoleded rooms and were extremely pleased with the decor. Wood and modern painting schemes, in white and spa green, made it feel cosmopolitian while new mattresses with down comforters made it comfortable. The bathrooms were redone in marble and are spacious and functional and the small refridgerator came in very handy. I liked the amenties so well I took some of them home. For those on a budget I recommend buying your breakfast items at the local grocery store and enjoy them on your lanai (balconey) each morning. Haliewa, a small surfing town, has some inexpenive and very good eating establishments and is well worth the visit. For incidentials avoid the resort stores and try Wal Mart or Ross instead. I typically will buy an "Entertainment Book" for Hawaii online prior to our visit and have saved hundreds of dollars on meals and attractions. When we leave I will usally leave the book for the maid or someone who has helped us during our stay. The North Shore is a wonderful place to experience the true Hawaii it is not rich nor fancy but real and beautiful. I have always found the locals to be friendly and helpful and as long a you respect them and their home, they will go out of their way to help you. So, remember to use "Mahalo" (thank you) alot and enjoy your stay.

Reviews.Title: “Fabulous stay, and fabulous return stay....along with a few pointers”
Reviews.Author: jerseygirlphotos
Reviews.Content: We visited Turtle Bay Resort for the first time in 11/2005. We loved everything about the resort, and I booked a return trip for 7/2006 as a graduation gift to my daughter. Turtle Bay is located on the North Shore of Oahu, which is about an hour north of the Waikiki/Honolulu area. Both visits were fabulous. I will point out some differences to those who might not be sure when in the year is best to visit this beautiful island. Our November trip to the North Shore was more crowded, both at the hotel and the North Shore area in general. This is due to the surfing contests in town. However, crowded is nothing like the crowds we experience here at the jersey shore in the summer, but croweded compared to my second visit in July. November seemed warmer to me, and less windy. There was rain almost daily in the fall, however a short lasting mist early in the day, nothing that stops you from going about your daily activities. The landscaping was lush and green, and we were able to visit Pearl Harbor in less than 1/2 day. July 2006: It was windy at the North Shore! You had to anchor your light items in place or they would blow away. In New Jersey we would call this "gale winds", in Hawaii they are known as "trade winds".. This is not necessarily a bad thing, but it was much much windier in July than in November and this seems to be the norm from what I was told by the locals. Because of this, it seemed a little cooler, however I did not notice the winds in Waikiki, and the winds did not stop us from swimming, it just seemed a little cooler and less humid than it was in November. The North Shore was nearly deserted too. There are no waves here during the summer months, so the surfers are not around and the traffic is practically non existant in this area. The North Shore is quiet compared to Waikiki any time of year, but in this little town with a two lane road, traffic in the winter months does back up. The North Shore area, including Turtle Bay Resort, seems to close down for the evening early. No drinks at the pool late at night because the poolside bar closes at 9 pm. Things get very quiet at night, so if you are looking for nightlife, you are better off in Waikiki. Waikiki incidentally, is about an hour's drive south of Turtle Bay Resort. We made the trip a few times in a rental car and it's not a bad ride. If I have the chance to visit this island again, I might stay a few days in Waikiki, then head over to the North Shore. That would probably be the way to experience the best of both worlds when visiting this wonderful island. About the resort itself: the rooms are large, clean, nicely decorated and comfortable. The down comforters on the beds are very nice. The beds are comfortable. The lanais are spacious and just about every room offers an ocean view, although the higher you are (floors 5-6), the better your view. The food is good, the service outstanding. The prices are what you would expect in a resort like this ie: $12 cheeseburgers, $8 pina coladas. My daughter had just come back from an all inclusive vacation in Punta Cana and said the food in Hawaii was so much better....everything about Hawaii and this resort in particular was classy compared to Punta Cana she said. There is a grocery store 5 minutes from the resort, where I bought snacks and drinks for the kids, there is also a little store by the pool that offers the same, and that is an option as well. If you are on a strict budget, the prices of the food and drinks might be intimidating, but if you look at it as "I'm on vacation"...then you realize you're in Hawaii and this is what you pay. We ate off premisis alot and those prices are similar to what you would find on the mainland US. Try the shrimp trucks and the surf shack in town for an affordable taste of local cuisine! Horseback riding is a must do excursion, the trail runs oceanside for much of it and the staff is wonderful. The slide at the kids pool was a big hit, and the poolside wait staff was excellent and very attentive. The hotel offers a Luau which is nice, there is also a fabulous luau at the Polynesian Cultural Center about ten minutes up the road. Both offer a unique experience, the hotel's luau is smaller and more intimate, the Polynesian Cultural Center's luau is a lavish display and it's an experience that takes all day between visiting the center, the luau and the show. I can't say I prefer one over the other, they are both superb and it's a matter of personal taste as far as what type of luau experience you wish to have. The Polynesian Cultural Center is worth a visit regardless of whether you purchase luau tickets, it was definately one of my favorite parts of this trip.

Reviews.Title: “Wonerful time”
Reviews.Author: famoffivelgnniguel
Reviews.Content: My Husband and thre kids (14, 11 and 6) stayed at TBR for 5 nights. The hotel and grounds are beautiful. The food at Lei Leis is terrific. We played tennis golf and went horseback riding. The weather was great but unfortunately the waves were to dangerous for us to swim. I guess December is not a great time of year for beach swimming. The have a protective beach at the hotel that kids enjoyed. There are no waves it's more like a bay. We went hiking at Wailia falls and it was incredibly beautiful. You can hike (really walk) about 3/4 mile to beautiful waterfalls. My son and I went swimming under the falls. It was cold but a great expereince. The staff at the hotel is amazingly nice! When we arrived our room was not ready so they upgraded us to a suite. Right on the ocean! Each morning our three kids went down to breakfast on their own and the staff got to know them and after a day or so would bring them free hot chocolate and other goodies. We will definely go back to TBR but this time in the spring or summer.

Reviews.Title: “The final word on Turtle Bay:)”
Reviews.Author: LPC
Reviews.Content: Spent four days here after Christmas with my two teenagers. Came from three days at the Halekulani. In short? There are ways to enjoy this place and ways not to. If you have the right expectations and work at getting the right room for your expectations you will be in good shape and really enjoy yourself. Otherwise? No. The setting is beautful - that is the shoreline is beautiful. The workers are lovely and very accomodating and friendly. The food at Ola's and the Palm Court breakfast buffet (only things we tried,) is average for luxury accomodations, meaning pretty darn good. However, the hotel is worse than people are letting on. First, the lobby has the feeling of a convention center. And someone had the terrible idea to put yellow light in the ceiling light boxes. And the breakfast place, the Palm Court, has no doors and is open at the end of the lobby which means that that awful industrial food smell is prevalent, not always, but often enough. Eek. Second, the hotel from the outside is also poorly designed. While the bay and cove are nice, to get to them when you walk outside the hotel you go down a LOOOONG concrete stairwell. And then you see the hotel trucks and storage area. And occasionally smell the garbage. And when you walk from the cove to the bay, you have to walk all around what is essentially a large concrete basement, with conference rooms and wedding spaces above that are kind of like walking near small city buildings. Needless to say, there are no photos of this on the website. But that wedding point they show? Fronted by a lot of 70's concrete. So even the lovely setting around the hotel itself is not perfect. Eek. Third, the rooms are spartan. And not spartan like the Post Ranch Inn or Hotel Healdsburg. Spartan like a slightly more tasteful and rural Marriott. Also, the king rooms just don't have enough furniture:). No arm chair, slightly scarred desk, etc. Bathroom with nice pale green marble tiles but oldish painted wood cabinets with no detailing and oldish tile and dirty grout in the bathtub. And no separate shower, yup, you are in there with the plastic shower curtain and it is not pristine. And someone, probably the same person who put the yellow lights in the lobby, has painted the walls a green that's supposed to be Restoration Hardware celadon but is actually more hospital. Eeek again. Now, if you play your cards right, as other people have said, you can get a room high up. Much more important than Deluxe, which gives you a bigger lanai but a view of the roof. Yes, we were in one of those first too:). So best in-hotel strategy is to spend as little as possible for as high a room possible that faces either the swimming cove or the surfing bay. Ask when you call. And, for those who can spend money, the Beach Cottages look great. I didn't reserve one because I was afraid they were too isolated for my teens. No. They are just across a little bridge. I didn't see the inside, but they sound pretty nice. And the big plus is that they have a lawn in front, look right at the surfing bay, and have hammocks and lawn chairs. Now THAT's Hawaii...And you rarely have to pass the concrete basement. and conference room areas, or the garbage, etc. Horseback riding is great, snorkeling is OK, there are secluded beaches on the property you can have all to yourself, the food is pretty darn good, and the service is very very nice. Really they ought to smash the conference rooms, and redo the lobby, and refurnish the rooms. But, as the only game in town, and all of us willing to pay $500 for rooms in high season, why would they. So either spend the big bucks for a Beach Cottage and eat at Ola's and go into Halaeiwa and go horseback riding, and take picnics to the secluded beachs,etc and enjoy the North Shore, or, wangle the lowest cost possible for a high floor room of whatever size, don't eat the hot buffet, and you can stay in a world class spot for a reasonable price. In case you need to know where I have traveled to put my review in context, Four Seasons Haulalai, Halekulani, Club Meds (yes why not), Hotel Healdsburg, Ritz Carlton NY, Jamaica Inn Ocho Rios, Royal Hawaiian, Post Ranch Inn, St. Regis Shanghai, etc.. My favorites are the Post Ranch Inn and the Ritz Carlton NY. Rural luxury where that's appropriate, city luxury where that's appropriate. Have a great stay!

Reviews.Title: “If you must do Oahu, stay at Turtle Bay”
Reviews.Author: southamericantourist
Reviews.Content: Stayed at Turtle Bay for 4 nights over winter break with my husband. Having just come from Kauai, we really enjoyed how remote and pristine the north shore of Oahu was (a trip down to over-commercialized, noisy, polluted Waikiki for New Year's Eve festivities confirmed that for us). I agree with the reviewers who said that Turtle Bay Resort is a 2-star hotel in a 5-star setting, but the setting makes it all worthwhile! Not only is the resort located on an amazing coastline (with monster waves the days we were there--not great for swimming but great for spotting 20-foot waves and surf champions), the North Shore of Oahu has preserved its laid-back way of life. Groups of surfers ambling along with their boards tucked under their arms, children bicycling alongside the road, fruit stands selling fresh pineapples and leis, homemade pickled mango stands and shacks selling burgers and hotdogs to famished beachgoers--staying at the North Shore is adopting for awhile the attitude that nothing is important enough to stress over. It was tough to get to from Waikiki due to the 1-land road, but I'm happy that is so, because I'll be very sad when the North Shore becomes commercialized. Turtle Bay resort itself was just fine. Not great, but not bad. The property is a bit older, and it is starting to show. We arrived late and were put into a very nice, large, clean room on the 2nd floor with the worst view possible--basically a slate roof, with a peek at the ocean beyond. I called down to the front desk immediately and was told (pleasantly) that they were full for the night, but if I stopped by the desk the next morning I could get a room on a higher floor. I did just that, and the sweet-mannered clerk immediately put me into a room on the 6th floor, with a view of the beach. When we transferred over, we saw that we had a much smaller lanai and the room itself was smaller and dingier, with dirtier caulking in the bathroom and (strangely enough) worse amenities. I think this is because the South Tower was renovated a longer time ago, so next time I would ask for a high floor in one of the other towers. Also, the housekeeping wasn't as thorough as at some of the other 4 or 5-star hotels I've stayed at. Nonetheless, the simply furnished room and laid-back, friendly Hawaiian style service was perfect for a beach stay. Who wants to stay at a stuffy ritz-carlton resort when the vacation is all about being sandy and suntanned and relaxing? Other things to note: we loved Ola, the restaurant on the beach, which had amazing views and great food, especially the garlic edamame. Lei Lei's was just okay (pretty ordinary and not a great location), and Hang Ten had terrible food but great drinks and amazing views of surfers/waves. Foodland market and Starbucks is about 10 minutes down Kamehaha Highway (take a right turn exiting the resort). There is an empty fridge so get all your drinks and snacks and store it in your room to avoid paying for expensive bottled water. Last, its not worth going to Waikiki! Stay at Turtle Bay and enjoy the North Shore lifestyle.

Reviews.Title: “Worth Every Dollar...Amazing”
Reviews.Author: TheBullBoston
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a 10 night stay at the Turtle Bay Resort over Christmas. The hotel is amazing. Located on one the most beautiful and secluded spots on the North Shore complete with surfers, sandy beaches, and (2) 18 Championship golf courses. Like others have pointed out, its pricey but in my opinion worth every dollar. Just for comparison, it was the same as the Hilton Hawaiian Village in Honolulu was for the same 10 nights. I know this because I cancelled my reservation at the Hilton and came out here. Best decision I ever made. Rooms: It's not the Venetian in Vegas folks so it is what it is. Similar to a Hilton/Sheraton standard room. I had a 6th floor room with balcony overlooking the pool and sunset beach. Outstanding 180 degree view of the pacific ocean. Maid service was excellent and room service fast and hot. Pools/Beaches: Incredible pools and beach. Ocean water was 78 degrees. Pool water was 65-75 depending on which pool you went in. Also they have (2) jacuzzis which were easily available and a small waterslide for kids and adults that dumps into a small pool with a waterfall. When you're not swimming you can watch the surfers ride the waves about 50 yard away or order food/drinks at the pool. People were partying which was nice. There is also a bar at the pool with plasma tvs too. Golf: I went for golf. Played both the Palmer and Fazio courses twice each, Place was empty so I had no problem teeing off whenever I wanted. I played either at 8am or 2pm to avoid the heat and strong sun of midday. Courses are really nice and really hard especially the Palmer Course. It hosts the Sr PGA in Jan. so its a challenging track. Fazio is a bit more open but still a good test. Tees, Fairways, Greens on both were manicured to perfection. Had a private lesson and it was perfect. Larry is a great Pro. Teahes to your ability and style and really cared about how I played after the lesson and was always offering help. Pro shop and staff were great and professional. Say hello to Andy and the rest of the guys who take the bags. Tip them, they deserve it. Food/Drink: I ate virtually all my meals at Lei Lei's at the golf course, Its cheaper, better tasting and a better value than the room service or the restaurants. That's just my opinion but you decide. Say hello to Ian, Tyler, Lalani (sp) and the rest of the staff who work the bar/restaurant. Lei Lei's is a great place to hang and share a drink after a round of golf or a nightcap. Summary: Turtle Bay was an amazing vacation for me. All I will say is that it can be pricey if you partake in everything here. Golf, horseback riding, spa treatments, at great restaurants cost alot so expect to pay for it. If you're looking for a Motel 6 value then this isn't for you. It's an upscale hotel in a very secluded part of Oahu. There is no reason to leave this place once you get there so sit back and enjoy it. Go for a swim, take a horseback ride and relax and stop worrying what it will cost. This place will make you forget about the day to day. Mahalo Turtle Bay. Mahalo. See you next year.

Reviews.Title: “Number one bc its the only one”
Reviews.Author: zosoboogie
Reviews.Content: Usually when I have nothing to say I dont say anything at all. However I felt milked everyday, I found out that if you charge it to your room there is an additional fee. The towel cards we a pain in the rear and if you dont return them it is a charge of $25 per card. All the fees and other charges to the room were too much I booked a long time ago for my honeymoon and for two night with all the fees I paid about $800. However the resort grounds was beautiful, Learned how to surf and it is hard. The room was average but spacious and if I were to go back I would visit but not stay. We also ate at Lei Lei and it was a great meal the dessert was to die for.

Reviews.Title: “You're better off renting a beach house.”
Reviews.Author: katiemo13
Reviews.Content: My boyfriend and I just got back from a four night stay at Turtle Bay Resort. We were rather disappointed with our stay. From the beginning, we were made to wait in line to check in, while there was just one person working behind the desk. This made for a slow moving line, especially when he was also required to answer the front desk phone. This was not a good start to our vacation, a comment that was shared by another couple while we all waited in line. Once we made it to our room, we were not impressed. We had booked a Deluxe Ocean View room, and while we could see the ocean, most of our view was of the roof below. The room itself didn’t seem to have any of the amenities that one would expect from a resort. The shampoo and conditioner were no better than what you’d see at a Marriott. The sheets and towels were low quality, and our shower wasn’t cleaned properly. Also, the idea of charging $3 for bottles of water on top on our room rate is preposterous. And then a $15 charge to use the showers after we’d checked out? While the grounds lived up to a bit more of the standards one holds for a resort, I would still call them far from stellar. The swimming pool was ice cold, it would have been a refreshing treat had we been able to bare the temperature. The towel cards were quite a nuisance, shouldn’t a resort allow guests to the luxury of more than one towel at a time? Overall, we left Turtle Bay vowing not to come back, and to share with our friends who may be traveling to North Shore that renting a beach house is a much better route to go. It’s a shame that TBR is taking advantage of its monopoly as the only hotel in the area, and giving their guests the bare minimum. I’m just sorry we hadn’t been warned first.

Reviews.Title: “Very Poor Property”
Reviews.Author: twopisces
Reviews.Content: I think we would be doing a diservice by not writing a review of this property. First off, this is one of the more expensive properties to stay at on the North Shore of Oahu. We arrived to find that while the hotel had undergone cosmetic upgrades, it was in somewhat run down condition. Other than new paint throughout there were many signs that the building was more than 25 years old. Cracked concrete, peeling wallpaper in the hallways, carpet seams that were coming apart etc. Behind the reception desk there were dirty handprints down the walls leading to the office, just odd for a 4 star property. The reception desk personnel had problems finding our reservation even though we had made it months before. When we finally got checked in we went to our room and found that the carpets and bedding were damp, likely from salt air making its way through the ventillation system. The room also had a musty odor. There was rust on anything that was steel in the room such as light switch plates,sprikler heads etc. When we complained we were offered two other rooms that were just as damp as the first room. It took us a full day and much effort to get this hotel to offer a refund for the second night. We were lied to by the night manager about who could authorize the refund (He told us that it would have to come from Expedia, not true!) Aside from one day manager, the front end staff in this hotel are not well trained. We had to pay an extra $ 15 dollars for parking, went out for dinner the first night and came back to find that there was no parking. In short, if you truly know what quality properties are like then you best avoid this hotel. If you don't mind 2 - 3 star properties and don't mind paying $200-300/night then this hotel is fine. It does have a beautiful view and some nice beaches.

Reviews.Title: “Second Stay, cant wait for our third”
Reviews.Author: lucy8181
Reviews.Content: This was our second stay at TB and will not be our last. The first time we had a deluxe room in the main hotel, that was great, this time we decided on a suite. The 11th hour we decided up up grade to a cottage and so glad we did. Also, extended to five nights instead of three. The cottages are expensive, but well worth it. They are spacious, very clean and private, or so we thought. Several times when we were sitting on our back deck, enjoying quiet, hotel guests would stop and ask about the cottage. Fine. But, we were rather upset when someone walked into our cottage to see it. People staying in the cottages spend alot of money to do so and one reason is for selclusion, not be be bothered by other guests. People who want to view the cottages need to ask at the front desk. This is in no way a reflection on the hotel. Just beware cottage dwellers. We ate at all the restaurants except Ola's. All we very good, service was good. Giovannis shrimp truck, was not very good, would not go back . They run out of everything too. Go to the shrimp trucks early. Ted's bakery is very good. The Pipeline and Sunset Beach are wonderful. Make sure you have a car, convertable is the best and worth the extra $$. The pool water is rather cool, and I agree does need new tiles. Hot tub could be bigger and one was not working. We went to the spa and had a couples massage. Very nice. Back to the cottage, aside from the above noted problem, they are wonderful. Directly on the beach. Hammocks available for sunsets or just to relax. The private butler was awsome. They will fill your tub for a hot bath with candles and champagne. Bring you ice, make dinner reservations for you, anything. They arranged for a private dinner on our deck at sunset. Complete with white linen tablecloths, candles, flowers and champage. This is what TB is all about. It was very romantic. The luxury and service in the cottages are worth every penny. We will return in a couple years and stay in the cottage again. We have stayed in six other resorts in Hawaii plus have done a seven night cruise. TB is our favorite. We will always retun here.

Reviews.Title: “relaxing resort”
Reviews.Author: ftbud
Reviews.Content: we stayed at this resort over Thanksgiving for 9 days. I was a little aprehensive given some of the mixed reviews i read on this location. Overall we had a good time. The rooms could definitely use updating, but our 2 rooms were clean. We did have a problem with our thermostat, and it was promptly replaced. The views from our rooms were terrific. The pool area is well taken care of; service for the bar/food was very good. The pool water was very cold though! Great views of surfers right off the pool. beaches on both sides of the hotel. Snorkeling was not as good due to high waves this time of year. This side of the island is pretty laid back; this is the only hotel/resort here. Food: our 'package' included breakfast buffet, which was not only good, but conveinent and saved a lot of money. On site is also Lei Lei's (at the golf course) which had excellent food. Also on site is Ola, which is on the beach, had excellent food as well. Overall the staff at the hotel and restaurant were very good. We did go to Waikiki twice, once to check out this beach (our two boys had never been there) and once to hike Diamond Head and snorkel at Hanama Bay. Also spent one day at the Polynesian Culture Center: These trips were good, but for laid back relaxing Turtle bay is a great place!

Reviews.Title: “Amazing!”
Reviews.Author: Bessca
Reviews.Content: This hotel is amazing. We had to get out of Waikiki because tourist central is not our idea of Hawaii. We were so glad we did, in fact, we wished we would have never stayed in Waikiki at all. We booked our hotel the day before arrival online, and got a gorgeous room for $199 a night. They even upgraded us when we got there becuase I had a "I prefer" frequent hotel card. There are gorgeous ocean views from every room. The bathrooms are huge also! Just watch out for the fruit flies, we had to have them come up and spray, don't make the mistake of leaving your door open at night, that is when they came in. To top it off, we saw Bethany Hamilton surfind right in front of the hotel one day! (She is the surfer who had her arm bitten off by a shark a few years ago, when she was only 15) Seriously, stay at this hotel! We went horseback riding on the beach and it was awesome! Also, for food, drive 15 minuted to Haleiwa (pronounced Haleeba by the locals). There is the best Thai food we ever had at a place called Haleiwa Eats. Bring your own beer or other alcohol though, its a BYOB place.

Reviews.Title: “Paradise, Beautiful, loved Turtle Bay!”
Reviews.Author: JenandJim
Reviews.Content: I was a little concerned once I landed in Honululu as the traffi and congestion was aweful. Than I began my drive North-Breathtaking! O.K. so here are my reviews: Rooms-Very Very nice, not the Four Seasons, but clean and tidy. Be sure to get Ocean View Deluxe- there is a difeence. We had room 620-try and request this room, BEST views from balcony. SEE PHOTOS. Sunset sun up every morning!! The balcony is amazing-the views even better!! ONLY DOWNFALL: Pillows-the pillows are bad. AND do not leave fruit in room, there are alot of fruit flys. Hotel-WOW! The lobby will leave you gasping for air!! Pools- AWESOME! Never crowded-one heated one refreshing. One pool slide, great drinks by the pool, great scenery! Resturants: Ate at them all, 21 definitly my fav but very pricy. WORTH IT. Lei Leis was our best meal. The pool bar had pool food, and the Palm Terrace is where we ate breakfast every morning. It came with our package-of you can get that buffet, do it! WOW, great selection and very tasty! It will keep you filled until dinner! STAFF: FRIENDLY, helpful ENTERTAINMENT: Well, there really is not any here at the hotel. This is our downfall on the Hotel. Friday nights there is a Lua Show. ADVISE: Rent a car! Once you arrive in Honolulu take the route up towards Halewai and the Dole Pineapple grounds-less sceneic, but NEED to see. Start your vacation off by stopping in Halewai (15 minutes from Hotel) and get a Matsomodos shaved ice--get it with ice cream and beans..OH MY GOSH! The best! One day (Full Day) take the scenic route, east on 83 in otherwards make a left out of the resort and spend the day at the Waimaile waterfalls. It is an all day affair-DO NOT FORGET bug spray and good water shoes! It is worth the trip. You can swim in the bath of the falls at the end. It is hard to find, one tip: When you get to a black bench towards the end, go down the steep stairs, go into the river and follow it left, there you will find the falls! One day drive to Pearl Harbor, well this is imporessive-brought me to tears! We left the Hotel at 7:30 Got there at 8:30 left at 3:00, went to the Dole Pantation and headed to Halewai for a sunset dinner at Jameson's by the Sea. WOW...Awesome! Great place to eat!! We also went to Sharks Cove for snorkeling, GREAT snorkeling...a little dangerous. Go to Turtle Beach to swim with Sea Turtles, that was neat!! Sunsets, Sunset Beach--- We tried Giovannis shrimp truck, I think we are the only ones that did not like it. For grovereies, go to FOODMART-there is one left or right out of the resort. There is a Starbucks on the one to your right. Get a card, free it will save you a bundle of money! Things to see: The "Biouj" somethingTemple-Dole Pineapple-Waterfall-Macadamia Outlet-Turtles- Lua-Polynesian Cultural Center...For a few drinks go to Breakers in Halewai--it is a little more hip, music dancing sometimes ect... The Hotel just put in while we were there many more unbrellas on the beach. The snorkeling is not good here, but the neach itself is breathtaking!!! Julia Roberts was here earlier in the year with the twins! MANY stars so bring your camera!!! All in all in was a 91/2 MAHALO! Very romantic place,peaceful! Great for weddings or couples

Reviews.Title: “Near Perfection”
Reviews.Author: Kathy1007
Reviews.Content: My husband & I just returned from 8 nights at Turtle Bay and would love to return again anytime. We have traveled quite a bit and we both felt this is the most picturesque resort we've ever stayed at. It's pricey compared to Mexican or Carribbean resorts but worth every penny. The rooms are lovely, clean, updated and you have a view of the ocean from nearly every room. We were on the 5th floor and upgraded to a larger lanai as we like to sit outside in the morning. The only disappointment was that we had 2 queen beds instead of a king. The beds were very comfortable with soft down quilts. The view was best from the higher floors. The pool was very large and kept immaculate. The grounds as well were thoroughly maintained. The spa was adequate - nothing special. The food at the restaurants was very good. The only place we did not eat at was 21. Lei Lei's (at the golf course) was the best place for lunch or dinner. The Palm Terrace had a great breakfast buffet. The staff was very pleasant and eager to please. As for Golf, the Fazio course was a disappointment, however, the Palmer course was fantastic. I did wonder why they didn't lay out more holes along the ocean. You really only saw the surf from the 17th green on the Palmer Course. There were several walking paths along the courses for exercise, however, they were poorly marked and hard to follow. All in all, it was a lovely vacation and we would love to return again.

Reviews.Title: “Perfect mix of seclusion and adventure for the honeymoon”
Reviews.Author: larpov
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed here for the first 4nights of our Honeymoon at that Hawaiian Islands. We stayed in one of the Beach Cottages--WOW! What an amazing experience. Total luxury, seclusion and fabulous services. Everyday something new was delivered to our suite, whether it be champagne, Mai Tai's, to extoic fruit and a relaxing bath service prepared while you're out. Not to mention the restaurants in this Resort are to die for: 21 Degrees North for a splurge, but honestly excellent food, drinks and desert; Ola is great for fish, esp. Butterfish (really good mild fish). Its location is perfect for daily adventures, so be sure to scope out the nearby famous beaches: Bonzai Pipeline, Sunset Beach, Shark's Cove for amazing snorkeling, and Waimea Bay Audubon Center (for a great hike and waterfall shot!). For a cheaper lunch alternative, try Ted's Bakery (quick delicious sandwiches, and you must try their Chocolate Haupia pie!).

Reviews.Title: “Nice view and but run down”
Reviews.Author: lc2cassina
Reviews.Content: Nice ocean front view and view of turtles in the bay but the property was run down. The airconditioning was so loud that my wife could not sleep. The next day went through the usual "they all do that," "I don't even hear the airconditioning'" to "the airconditioning was brand new..." Switched rooms but not much better. My wife actually wanted to come back immediately from Hawaii but could not make the flight so stayed a second night and cut our trip short. It was such a negative experience that my wife does not want to go back to Hawaii ever - and she's been bugging me to take her to Hawaii for years! I have to acknowledge the resort in that the manager credited me for the unused days, which was something I was worried about from reading the Tripadvisor reviews.

Reviews.Title: “Nice Hotel...Enjoyed our stay”
Reviews.Author: Joanne73
Reviews.Content: We stayed at the Turtle Bay Resort in October 2006 for 3 nights. We went to Hawaii for our honeymoon and Oahu was the first of 3 islands we were visiting. We definitely enjoyed our stay - we were in the deluxe oceanfront (w/large lanai). The hotel is definitely not near the hustle and bustle of Waikiki, which was what we were looking for, so we thought. It was almost an hour from the airport. I think if we were to go back, we'd rather stay in the Waikiki area. We figured since it was our honeymoon, we'd want to be in a somewhat secluded resort and do nothing but relax. We actually got to see some parts of the island that we would not have gotten the chance to see if we didn't stay on that side of the island - it was definitely worth it and we don't regret staying there. The prices are fairly reasonable - we got a great rate through the hotel website if you prepaid for the stay, which we did. Food is not cheap - we paid $20 each for breakfast, which was so-so. Dinner cost us about $120 at one of the restaurants at the hotel - can't think of the name of it right now, but it began with an L and it was in a separate area, not inside the hotel itself - but it was delicious! The hotel staff was very friendly and helpful. They gave us good ideas on what to do/where to go and were helpful with directions. The room was nothing spectacular, but it was nicely decorated...nothing fancy, and clean which is the most important thing to us. Overall, we were happy with our choice of hotel and recommend it.

Reviews.Title: “Turtle Bay review by repeat visitor”
Reviews.Author: proudnewdad
Reviews.Content: Having stayed at Turltle Bay about 15 times over the last 3 years I thought I would bring some clarification to prior reviews. I have stayed at TB both before and after the current renovation. Yes the mgmt style has changed since Hilton ran the property but then any company that has pumped millions into a renovation needs to show a profit. Even with said, it is still a reasonably priced hotel. If you do not like the price quoted on-line then call the reservations number as I have found they always are willing to offer something cheaper. TB is not a 5 star resort. You stay at TB to get away from the congestion of Waikiki with such a great location and so much to do. Yes the food at TB is expensive but Haleiwe is just a 20 minute drive away with Hakuku less than that. If you want to be treated like a prince then stay at one of the expensive hotels around Waikiki. TB is simply a very nice hotel away from the madness of Waikiki. I would not recommend TB for first time visitors to Oahu since it is an hour's drive from Honolulu.

Reviews.Title: “Bring Money: Food is Way Too Expensive and Not Worth The Price”
Reviews.Author: Supersuperbob
Reviews.Content: We spent nine nights at Turtle Bay. We chose TB because of its remote location and that the resort was rated as being excellent. The location is fantastic. We loved the area and that it was far from being tourist oriented. That said, we both felt that the Turtle Bay Resort was not worth the price we paid. The hotel is starting to show its wear and tear. The first room we were offered had a wall that had been touched up three or four times. The differences in color and that it had been touched up was obvious. The tile around the swimming pool is cracked and in some places tiles are missing. Hotel staff are friendly and willing to please. Most of all, staying at Turtle Bay means you're captive to eating in one of the resorts restaurants. There are no decent restaurants in the immediate area. Yes there's a McDonald's 20 minutes away and several local places but nothing worth writing home about. Turtle Bay's restaurants are expensive. Expect to spend a lot for what I would term an average meal at any of the six restaurants. The best deal is the evening buffet for $28. It's offered 3 or 4 nights each week. In addition, if you can add on to your vacation package the free morning breakfast buffet do it. This will save you money and start your day off on the right foot. If you're looking for a Foodie vacation experience, avoid Turtle Bay Resort. If I had it to do over again I'd not vacation here. Oh yes, Alamo rental cars? Complete junk. Every Chrysler convertible I looked at were scratched and in poor condition. I finally settled for an upgrade at no cost for a VW convertible with few miles. I saw one man check in his second rental car in exchange for a third: Problem were with tires not remaining inflated. Go with another company while on Oahu.

Reviews.Title: “Week long stay in a suite”
Reviews.Author: airboyd
Reviews.Content: We stayed in a Pikake Suite for 5 nights. If you sign up for the iprefer.com membership, it let's you get a great rate on the Junior Suites and they are only slightly more than a regular room but is bigger with better views. Our room had a great view of the point that the resort sits on and we watch the sunset from our lanai every night. We walked the oceanside trails to the ends of the resort in both directions. Each walk is probably about 2 miles each way. There was no issues with the trail markings as previously reported. You really don't need trail markings for the beach walks or the golf course walks. It's a big property but there's really no way of getting lost on it. My favorite restaurant was Ola. We also ate at the Hang Ten Bar & Grill, 21 Degrees North, Palm Terrace and Lei Lei's Bar and Grill. Each bar on the resort (and the island) makes their Mai Tai drinks differently. It's worth trying the different recipes. As reported the Hang Ten Bar & Grill is a little bit more expensive than the other lunch menus, but it was worth it. I felt that 21 Degrees North could have been better both in food and atmosphere, but the wait staff were excellent. Mitch really went out of his way to take care of us. We did not have any issues with service the whole time there. We were greeted promptly at every restaurant and everyone was attentive and polite. Check in and check out was quick. The rooms were clean and the staff was nice. We did not see any bugs anywhere. The resort spends countless hours cleaning all the glass windows and everything else. We recommend a rental car. Foodland is a grocery store on the way into TBR. The Pikake rooms have a small refrigerator and Foodland has some great sandwiches. Everything is reasonably priced there. You should also by some of the "reef shoes" there for walking on the volcano rock.

Reviews.Title: “Great location, average everything else”
Reviews.Author: JPRay
Reviews.Content: This review might help those looking for a stylish or European standard kind of place, at least to manage expectations. After reading about the renovation and excellent reviews in the guides, and paying $580 plus per night for the cabanas, I was expecting similar experiences to maybe Parrot Cay or Banyan Tree or Amanyara or a 4 Seasons. It was not to be! The location is wonderful and if you like walking, you can get to almost-deserted beaches surrounded by forests right out of the main area. Yet the quality of service and the experiences would have been acceptable if I'd paid $150 a night, but not for what they charge. The company that owns the resort seems solely interested in making the most money as possible, and I also had a feeling (although not corroborated) that they do not employ many local Hawaiians. They sub-contract many of their services, which are sub-standard and nobody seems to know much about them anyway, their excuse always was that "they are another company". The rental bikes (at $16 for 1.15 hrs) were falling appart and the outfit that rents them very unfriendly. We had pre-arranged kayak rentals and was shocked to discover on the day that I needed to drive to another location 30 mins away to rent them as this so-called resort does not rent them. When we arrived to the resort, the check-in person failed to give us any information, or breakfast vouchers, and check-out took more than one hour as we had to cancel a charge. In themselves, these problems were minor and I would normally not be bothered by them, but they soon started to accumulate. The spa was another experience of sub-contractors being incompetent (we had 2 massages booked at the same time and they failed to tell us that the same masseur would be doing them, thus one having to wait in the corridor for one hour before getting the massage). And the spa's location feels almost like it's in a parking lot, not particularly relaxing. The gym is OK, but again, nothing compared to what you find in other establishments were you pay $580 per night. As for the cabanas, I liked the fact that you could walk directly to the door without having to get into elevators, etc. And, being directly opposite the beach was great (btw, the beautiful beach in front of the cabanas is very rocky and not safe for swimming). But I am not that sure that they offer that much more than the bigger rooms in the main building. In fact, the cabanas were quite strange in that they are huge but very dark. The bathrooms have been re-done and are lovely and comparable to nice European hotels, as is the amazing and superior huge bed. But everything else just looked like it belonged to a motel room. And they also charge $15 per day extra for services that most people do not use or that other hotels provide for free. So all in all, I maybe had a problem with expectations related to the reviews and the price. And there are some great things about TBR. The dedicated concierge for the cabanas is very friendly and efficient, probably the best service we had here and the food from 21 Degrees is really very good.

Reviews.Title: “Turtle Bay Resort - The true Hawaii!”
Reviews.Author: scorchestra
Reviews.Content: I love the Turtle Bay Resort! My heart literally aches to return! Last year we went to Oahu and stayed at Waikiki when we visited the North Shore we stopped by the TBR and saw the incredible lobby and asked to see a room. We loved it and I promised my husband and son that the following year we’d stay here. This year we did. We loved it! We stayed for two nights and 3 days before finishing our trip at Waikiki. I wish we had never left to Waikiki. I could have spent the entire 12 days for our Hawaii vacation at TBR. When you check in you will see a beautiful lobby. When you book do it through their website for the best deals. Keep checking for great deals they change often. Our room was on the 6th floor next to the presidential suite with sweeping views of the ocean. My favorite thing about this resort is that you could sit on the beach or float in the pool and see nothing but ocean and trees on either side of the hotel. It is not like crazy wild crowded Waikiki. The sign on the TBR says the true Hawaii and it is true you feel like it is the true Hawaii. I plan on retuning next year. This time we will stay at least 5 nights. The stay here is like being in paradise. The restaurants were all great. We ate at 21 degrees north, Ola, Lei’Leis and the Terrace for breakfast. They have 3 buildings. You simply cannot go wrong with any of them. All have great views! Truly I’d stay in any of them. There are two pools one large one and a smaller one with a fantastic slide that my 8 year old son loved. We had our best dinners of our entire stay at the Turtle Bay. Go to the beautiful 21 Degrees North Restaurant. The walkway to the restaurant is beautiful. It’s indoors but looks like a little tropical rainforest. We started off with one of the best Mai Tais we had. Extra strong and extra tasty. We had an appetizer but can’t recall what is was now! Our son had the Lobster (from the adult menu) he actually had the most expensive dish on the menu. His lobster was $46 My husband and I had a wonderful Hawaiian fish that they prepare with an amazing yellow curry (Hawaiian Moi Filet Nori Wrapped and Pan Seared with Peanut Oil, Sautéed Shiitake, Spinach, Jasmine Rice, Yellow Thai Curry, Coconut Cream Sauce 31.00 Nobilo, Sauvignon Blanc, New Zealand 10.00) I highly recommend it. We would sleep listening to the crashing of the waves. I recommend going to the Polynesian Cultural Center. It is great fun and worth every penny. My family and I really love all the cultural things and learning about other cultures. This is always a highlight for us. As you all know who have been there, the show from Samoa is great. The guy who does the show is also the star of the evening show “Horizons”. His name is Kap Teo and is very funny as well as very talented and the best fire dancer. At the end of the night we were very pleased to speak with him and purchase some of his art. He is a great artist. Dinner was wonderful. We did not do the Luau at PCC or eat there but instead went back to the resort to eat at their restaurant called OLA. It is on the beach and beautiful. We had Hawaiian fish (why eat anything else n Hawaii?). Miso Butterfish Sautéed Hamakua Mushrooms, Wilted Spinach and Kabayaki Butter $25.95 with Suggested Wine Pairing: Merry Vale Chardonnay . It was delicious and the service was wonderful. Back to the incredible evening show “Horizons”. After the show it was short 10-15 minute drive to our resort. It was sort of funny after the show because everyone, and do mean everyone, clears out right after for the long drive back to Waikiki. The gift shops are deserted so we wandered around then had that great talk with Kap Teo. Breakfast at Lei Leis. We had the famous breakfast croissant which is delicious and reasonably priced. We took it to go and ate it at one of the tables of Ola on the beach, which is closed since they only open for dinner. After Breakfast we took a walk on the Kulima Cove side. Other must do’s in North shore: Do not miss Romy’s Shrimp Hut or Aoki’s Shave Ice and Waimea Audubon Centre Gardens and waterfall. Please fell free to email if you have any questions. scorchestra@aol.com

Reviews.Title: “Great location”
Reviews.Author: bpotthoff
Reviews.Content: This is a really beautiful spot. We had a multi island trip (Maui, Big Island and Oahu). Everyone told me to pass on Oahu but I wanted to visit Pearl Harbor so we booked Turtle Bay to be away from the hustle and bustle of Honolulu. Honolulu is fun to visit but I was glad we stayed in the country. We're not big on night life. Join the Preferred Hotels club and you will get a better rate on this hotel. Our room was very nice. I found the service to be acceptable but not as good as at the Four Seasons on Maui or Mauna Kea on Big Island. The laundry here is a plus. We found the tennis here to be so-so. We ate at Ola's and Lei Lei's. The ambience at Ola's was great but the food was mediocre. The food at Lei Lei is great. We really loved the North Shore and the trip up there - via either way. Haleiwa is pretty. We ate at Jameson's there one night. The food was decent and the location very nice. We missed seeing the Polynesian Center. It rained the afternoon we originally planned to visit and we thought we'd visit Sunday. Unfortunately, it is closed Sunday. Pearl Harbor is worth visiting. They are serious about not bringing any bags or pocketbooks. You can bring a wallet and carry your camera. Leave everything else in the car. When we visited in mid-late Sept there was no need to go early in the morning to get a ticket. We walked in late afternoon and jumped on a tour. One tip is to be very careful driving up to the North Shore. The highway is one way each way. It is easy to have a fender bender. Our rental car was rear ended when we stopped at a cross walk to let a lady and her baby cross. Be careful and try to leave plenty of room between you and people ahead of you and behind you. We saw lots of other similar accidents. Last thoughts...this would be a stunning place for destination wedding. They have a glass chapel at water's edge. We saw a beautiful wedding there one night. This hotel is also very popular with the locals. Sept is apparently a slow month and the rates/availability are good.

Reviews.Title: “Lovely”
Reviews.Author: tyetye
Reviews.Content: We stayed for our honeymoon Im 23 aqnd husnband 25. free champagne in room. The rooms are decorated simple but cleanly. They have nice big bathroom. Daily Newspaper. The PIKAKE suite 583 had hug bathroom space. We had a huge balconey. 2.50$ per washer use. Nice sized pools and Jacuzzi. Plenty of beach right on premise. Golfing very nice. Tennis courts very nice. Do horseback ride its beautiful at night during sunset. Surf Lessons at Hans Hedeman at hotel- ASh was our instructor we caught a wave and surfed on the first try. Explore the beachs they are beautiful. Waimea beach has cliff jumping, Pupukea beach is nice and not very crowded, Hukilau beach was also very beautiful. Shop- if you like to shop go to Waikiki and shop the strip and Ala Moana mall. By far the mist beautiful mall, with every designer store and tons of eating places not to mention the Mai Tai Bar for great cocktails. Don Ho Show- Funny show but hes old and does not sing much. Cute show though. Hawaiian Music- House w/out a Key at the Halekulani is outside with ocean breezes great cocktails, soothing Hawaiian music, and miss Hawaii dance to it. Soo relaxing. DINING outside of hotel LUNCH DUKEs Canoe Club- Yummy food and drinks with outside ocean view of Waikiki beach. Giovannis Shrimp Trunk- On the North Shore shrimp scampi soo tasty with tons of garlic. Look for the white truck and lots of people. Kui Aina- Haleiwa location- such big juicy fresh burgers and shoestring fries. DINNER Ciao Mein- Waikiki Hyatt- Awesome food and service. Chinese and Italian fusion. DK Steakhouse- Waikiki- The best steak you will ever have will melt like butter in your mouth, its dry aged. Try the blue cheese butter. Michels- Nice location, food overpriced better food at the previous to restaurants for half the cost. Pineapple Room- Macys- in Ala Moana Mall- yes its in a mall but its well worth the time to sit and eat. Everything from drinks to dessert is soo wonderful. Island Burgers- Ala Moana Mall- Great juicy burgers and chicken sandwiches. Large appertizers and large cocoktails. Haleiwa Joes- Haleiwa- Awesome view outside of Harbor. Great service. Great seafood and decently prices. Cholos Mexican- In the Northshore Marketplace Haleiwa- better more authentic mexican then from where I live and great mojitos and margartitas to boot. Also not expensive. Also try a Malasada, Portugese doughnut. From one of their many trucks randomly placed in Haleiwa town. HOTELS RESTAURANTS 21 DEGREES NORTH- Yummy 21 different martinis. Stephanie the bartender makes the best Mojitos on the Island, their strong too. The food is small so we ordered a lot but it was all very tasty. They are expensive though. OLA- My favorite of all. Right on the beach on hotel property. All open aired the ocean waves sing to you during your meal. At lunch its a great spot for munchies and margaritas. During dinner tieme the tiki torches light the beach. The Kalua pig nachos are the best get them. The Butterfish melts like Butter and the Salmon is sugarcane crusted with sweet corn. The dessert martinis are also very tasty and desserts are great as well. The service is wonderful, ask for Krissy if shes still there. She was super sweet. We went there four times in 7 days for lunch and dinner. LEI LEIS- By the golf course. The food was great. The drinks were great. The Chocolate Cookie dessert was soo yummy!!! PALM TERRACE- Great buffet, different theme nights. We loved it for a laid back night. The breakfast buffet is also great. HANG TEN- Pool bar. They make great Mai Tais!!! The Sashimi was great, the caesar salad good, the garlic fries yummy. The waitress service to your lounge chair was on point I never didnt have a drink in my hand. All in all I guess thats it!!! Have fun!!! Aloha!

Reviews.Title: “Great Location, Nasty Bugs”
Reviews.Author: LovesSnorkling
Reviews.Content: Firstly, let me say the location is absolutely the best on the island of Oahu. That is what you are paying for:location. In contrast with Honolulu, there is no insane traffic and noise at all hours, here you will find privacy and peace (location wise). We saw black and white clown fish, seaturtles, and other abundant sea life. However, the rooms are lacking. The pictures shown on the hotel's web page put somewhat of a brighter glow on the condition of the rooms. We changed rooms because the first room we were assigned to had wet and musty carpet. The rooms are pretty dull and in need of another renovation. Amenities are strictly average. The best part of the room is the view of the ocean and the sound of the waves lulling you to sleep. Food was just ok. Service and food quality are best at LeiLei's. My major problem with this resort: COCKROACHES. They would crawl into the bathroom at night (we had to plug and block all drains), and we would find them in the room. The maids must not have done a very thorough job of cleaning because the dead bugs would still be there when we returned. We saw them in the hallways and in the buffet area on dining room chairs. On the last night of our stay, my fiance awoke to find one crawling on his face! When we approaced management about this issue, they vehemently insisted that it was impossible that there would be cockroaches as the hotel was regularly sprayed for bugs. Only when I offered to show the manager the pictures on my digital camera did he immediately change his tone. We were given a 25% discount off our stay. On a side note, definately check out Hanauma Bay when on Oahu. It is a beautiful snorkling spot and a great example of what nature can do when respected and left in peace. Please do not touch or step on the reefs, we saw many people breaking this rule and it was very sad....

Reviews.Title: “Another great stay, with only a few negatives...”
Reviews.Author: sahdoggiemom
Reviews.Content: My husband and I stayed at the Turtle Bay Resort September 1-4 which, in retrospect, was the worst time to schedule a romantic getaway. We had forgotten that it was Labor Day weekend and as such, the property was overrun (literally) with locals and their children. They dominated the entire property and made the pool areas incredibly stressful due to their screeching and yelling and rowdiness. This isn't the resort's fault, but keep in mind that in Hawaii, they like to get away on holidays as well and usually wind up at one of the local resorts. When we went back to the resort the following Thursday, all of the locals were gone and the resort was back to it's serene self. We'll remember this next time, and hope others can learn from our mistake. We did have a snafu at check-in, which always seems ten times worse at the time, especially after an 8-hour flight. I had reserved a king cottage, but when we checked in were given a double queen. While I understood bedding was not guaranteed, I indicated in the "guest requests" area of the reservation form and also contacted the Ho'okipa concierge (exclusive to the cottages) that this was a delayed anniversary trip (my husband had recently returned from Iraq) and we wanted one bed in our room. We finally were moved to a double queen (after way more begging than my husband should have had to do), and our personal concierge was great, but we only saw him once - upon reassignment to the new room. We did also experience a billing problem upon checkout, as it seems they forgot to check us out of the old room so we were being billed twice for everything. When we discovered this, we personally walked down to the front desk around 6 a.m. with the hopes of handling the issue in person, but were told it would have to be fixed later as the system wouldn't allow him to update our account. Huh? The cottages are beautiful and are well worth the price if you can manage to nail down a discounted rate, which we were able to do - $479 one night, and $541 the other two nights. Discounted of course, being a relative term and these rates did not count tax or the resort fee (please Turtle Bay, just roll that into the price so we don't feel like we're being nickle and dimed). The only other downside was the cottage next to us was occupied by no less than 8 people (locals), as we counted them coming in and leaving for half our stay. They weren't loud...but it just gave the place an air of tackiness as they played football in the green areas and ran around the area in front of the cottages like it was their front yard. I'd expect this in Vegas, but not in Hawaii. We immensely enjoyed our couples massage at Spa Luana, The facility is very nice, and the showers, steam room and open-air "relaxation area" were wonderful. Sure, it's pricey, but we felt we got more bang for our buck here than we did a couple of years ago at the Mandara Spa at the Hilton Hawaiian Village. We dined at Ola two nights, and our only negative is it seemed like our poor waiter was the only person working. There were wedding receptions being held both times we had dinner and it appeared as though too many folks were assigned to the receptions (of no more than 20 people) and one person got the rest of the guests. Strange. A word of advice - if you see tables set up for a reception, ask when you arrive to be seated away from the reception. We did get a bit of a glare when we requested this the second night, but our first evening's dinner was bruised and the romance killed by dealing with hovering reception guests snapping photos and blocking our view of the sand and ocean and generally getting into our personal dining space. The food was very good, but the mai tai's were rather weak. Go for the local beer, and you'll be better off. We also dined at Lei Lei's twice for lunch...can't beat the view of a beautiful golf course, and the food was fantastic. We never made it there for dinner, but hear that's the place to go for dinner. Overall, we had a wonderful vacation and are planning on staying in one of the villas next time, if we can swing it. If you visit the Turtle Bay Resort, be sure to get over to the actual Turtle Bay and watch the turtles come in to feed each day. They wandered in around 12:45 p.m. each day during our stay and stuck around for about 45 minutes. They truly are amazing creatures! Aloha!

Reviews.Title: “Great place to stay on the island of Oahu”
Reviews.Author: LoveHawaii49
Reviews.Content: We decided to stay at this resort, to avoid the crowds of Waikiki, and have a relaxing place to stay for 6 days. We loved our room, we could walk out onto our lanai, look down and see turtles swimming in the waters below. That was really exiciting. The room was a good size, and the lanai really made the room worth the money we paid. As for the service, it was mediocre. We are young, and when we pulled into the valet area, we were just given a "look" and asked if we were looking for parking. We informed the attendant that we were there to check in. Only then, did they offer to park the car and help with the baggage. Otherwise, the service was decent, nothing special. The resort pool was really nice, we really liked the bar by the pool. The beach was nice, however we only found a few cabanas, and they weren't in the best condition. The hotel should in the future provide more shade for their guests. Overall we had a good time at the hotel, we probably would not return unless there were improvements to the beach, and the customer service.

Reviews.Title: “Dream resort”
Reviews.Author: Kiwi75
Reviews.Content: Turtle Bay is a stunning resort far from the madding crowd. We stayed in the Beach Cottages and were able to watch the turtles surfing the waves just 10m away. What a unique experience. There are a variety of restaurants and good variety. The food and wine selection were of a high standard. The sporting facilities are of a high standard and there are many nice walks that one can take around the foreshore. Afternoon tea in the lobby is a treat! While expensive, the quotation the quality is remembered long after the price is forgotten is very true in respect of this resort.

Reviews.Title: “Turtle Bay - The North Shore Experience”
Reviews.Author: Marriedonmaui
Reviews.Content: Our visit to Turtle Bay Resort at Kahuku, Oahu, Hawaii was an excellent adventure with just one minor problem at check in. All rooms are ocean view and the south wing rooms all have a slight view of a conference room roof and a small lanai with just one chair. But as I found out when I complained “all rooms in the south wing - Kuilima Bay – can see the roofs from the lanais but they have the better bay/water/sun views”. They offered to move us, showed me the room on a map and we decided to stay right where we were. Good decision because after we walked around the resort we saw that the south wing had the better views for sure. The other wings do have larger lanais with two chairs instead of one – to some people that would make all the difference but to us it did not matter much as we just pulled one of the room chairs to the slider door and peace was restored. We further like our decision to stay where we were because each day at 1:00 the turtles came in to Kuilima Bay right in front of our room. They hung around 30 – 45 minutes eating algae and then off they went. Everyday like clockwork. The rooms are not that great décor wise but they are quiet, clean and the views are great. The beds are very comfy but a big down comforter that we promptly took off the bed for the entire stay. There were extra blankets of a normal weight in the closet so we put that one on the bed and I am happy to say that each day when housekeeping came, they left our bed that way and thankfully did not put back the down comforter back on the bed. The waves that were crashing all night outside our slider (which we left open all night ) was so peaceful and romantic but when we got home we had a hard time sleeping because there were no waves crashing outside our bedroom. The staff was great, very helpful, very friendly and we had no trouble with the resort staff at all. I must say that the views at TB, as nice as they are, can not compare with Kapalua Bay on Maui where we stay when on Maui, and where we were married on a seaside cliff in 2000. It has been torn down now for timeshares and our hearts were broken by that news but thankfully they can not take away the cliff we were married on. If you cancel anything at TB, recheck your bill on the t.v. before you get ready to check out so that you don't have to wait for corrections. We cancelled our seaside couples Lomi Lomi massage due to the weather but also because the gazebo has no roof so everyone walking by looks right in on you. We were still charged the $240 and we also had $43.20 on our bill from the spa. We had no spas services on this trip but I am happy to say that they did reverse them right away. Also, one night free valet was included in our package, and then you could self-park for free. Well, we were charged for the valet for every night - but again they reversed. All in all a great experience at TB and the north shore is heaven – Here a few things that we did on the north shore: There is a great place when you leave the resort heading towards Foodland, etc. that will be on the left side, directly across the street from the parking lot for Sunset Beach I think. They sell ice cold coconuts and pineapples. Look for the sign. Get one, take it to your room, make a Mai Tai in it and make yourself happy.
